Re Thunderchild Indian School.

Sir,-

Please find enclosed an invoice from Battleford Lumber and Supplies Limited, in quadruplicate, for $598.37 being cost of materials supplied at the above named school during construction of the new basement.

You will note that the Company made a slight mistake in computing the cost of one item.

As this was so small, I instructed Mr. Fetterly to change the item and initial it.

I would recommend that a cheque for $598.37 be sent to Battleford Lumber & Supplies Limited, of Battleford, Sask., in payment of this account.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 10, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, enclosing accounts in connection with the work at the Thunderchild Indian Residential School. A payment of $325.00 is being made to Rev. Father Allard, and the balances due L. A. Riches, A. Baldry, G. Cox and M. Quackenbush are also being paid.

Our Treasury Branch will not accept the account of $50 in favour of Father Allard. The account of November 6th, for wages for the four men mentioned above, stated that they were employed during the period September 17th to November 17th in connection with the water system. The account for $50 covers the period September 24th to September 29th. There is no explanation why the same men were employed at the same time in connection with the water supply system and in connection with excavating the cellar. In addition, the pay list for excavating the cellar is not receipted by the workmen.

North Battleford,
Nov. 19th 1934.

Dear Sir,

We thank you for your letter of the 14th inst., reference to a proposed pipe-line to be constructed near here.

We have no machine for trenching in the City. It is the general practice nowadays to use manual labour for this work. In Saskatoon, a far larger city than North Battleford all trenching is done by hand.

We estimate that the cost of digging such a trench as you specify would be approx. 65¢ per linear foot, using manual labour. This cost of course would vary slightly with local and soil conditions. The above estimate covers both the digging and backfilling.

You would be quite safe as far as the cost is concerned, in laying the pipe at a depth of nine feet. This is the usual practice here.

With reference to your 2" pipe, we do not know the kind of pipe you propose using, but would strongly advise you against using galvanised iron pipe, as with average soil conditions in this region the life of such pipe is only from ten to fifteen years.

Should this work be proceeded with, we would be in a position to materially assist you in the matter of your labour requirements, and would provide proper supervision of the work if you so desired. This is a branch of work of which we have considerable experience, and would suggest to you that proper supervision and experienced labourers would produce material savings in the cost of such a project.

Very truly yours,

(signed) M. Nowley.

Supt. of Water works.

O. H. Hoover, Esq.,
Engineer-in-Charge,
Calgary, Alta.

December 17, 1934.

Dear Mr. Murison:

You are, no doubt, aware that the Department has been acting in conjunction with the Dominion Water Power and Hydroelectric Bureau of the Department of the Interior in obtaining a water supply for use of the Thunderchild Indian Residential School. The Canadian National Railways, from whom the water supply was obtained, by a pipe-line from their water tank at the station at Delmas, near the school, have closed down this plant but have allowed the school authorities to operate same. It was considered advisable, a year ago, to endeavour to install a water supply system of our own for this school. The authorities of the Dominion Water Power Branch were consulted. They reported that water was not economically available from the Saskatchewan river, because of the distance, the difference in levels, possible impurities of the source and the cost of maintenance.

The Dominion Water Power Bureau recommended the drilling of a well and the installing of storage tanks in the basement of the school - the power for pumping water to be supplied by a gasoline engine and windmill used as auxiliary power. It was considered by them that an ample flow of water, sufficient for the needs of the school, could be obtained at a depth of from 250 to 300 ft. They estimated the cost of drilling the well, installing the pressure tanks and carrying out the alterations required to the basement; supplying windmill and gasoline engine to be approximately $8,700. They were authorised to proceed with the work. The

V. Murison, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Regina, Sask.
well has been drilled to a depth of 735 ft., with no water available, and the entire cost to date has been approximately $6,300.

The Dominion Water Power Branch now recommend that a pipe-line be installed from a spring located near the river and from which it appears that a plentiful supply of water can be obtained. It will be necessary to install the pipe-line a distance of 1½ miles. They have estimated the cost would be between $9,000 and $16,000, according to how the work is carried out.

The Department has spent considerable money in endeavouring to obtain a water supply, without result. We have no funds available to carry out the scheme which is now proposed by the Dominion Water Power Branch to install a pipe-line from the spring; and, in the meantime, the school authorities will have to carry on their present arrangement for obtaining a water supply from the Canadian National Railway System. We understand this is costing the school authorities approximately $100 per month to operate.

I shall be pleased if, upon the occasion of your next trip to the Battleford agency, you will visit the school, inquire into the water supply and submit a report, stating your opinion as to what should be done to provide this school with an ample supply of water. Any suggestions or recommendations you care to make will be appreciated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Re Thunderchild Indian School

Sir,

With further reference to my letter of 23rd ultimo regarding the well situation at the above named School, I wish to inform you that Father Allard, on his own initiative, requested the C.M.Miners Construction Company Limited, of North Battleford, to supply him with a rough estimate of excavating and back-filling a 9' trench 7500 feet long (not including cost of pipe or laying). They have not seen the location.

The Company stated that a rough estimate for this portion of the construction would be about $5500 for excavation and backfilling, or about 75¢ per running foot. Including pipe, the cost would therefore be about 1.10 per foot, which is not much different from Mr. Fetterly's original rough estimate.

Mr. L.A. Riches, of Unity, phoned me on Dec. 6 by long distance stating that neither he nor the other three men who had constructed the basement had as yet received their cheques. I informed him that the accounts were sent to Ottawa on November 21 but that the transmission of the cheques occupied a short time. No doubt they have received their wages by this date.

The above is given for your information.

Your obedient servant,

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK. 6th February, 1935.

Inspector's report on Thunderchild Indian Residential School - Battleford Agency

Sir:

I visited the above named school on January 14th and made a general inspection of the building and the classrooms.

I found the building kept in a very clean and tidy condition. The Reverend Father Allard, O.M.I., is the Principal. He is assisted by a competent staff. The care of the building and pupils is in charge of the Sisters of the Assumption. They are very thorough and competent in the discharge of their respective duties. The children presented a healthy and well nourished appearance. The health of the children at this school has been remarkably good during the present winter.

A farm is now being operated. Last season their crop consisted of 2,500 bushels of oats and 600 bushels of wheat. A half section of land has been rented on the Battle River for summer pasturage. In addition to the land farmed on the school property, the Principal rents land in the neighborhood for the purpose of growing green feed for the stock.

The livestock consists of 27 head of cattle and 4 work horses. They have 17 cows regularly milking. The children are given all the milk they care to drink. They have in addition 25 hogs and have been able to provide their own beef and pork requirements. The poultry consists of 80 fowl.

They grew an ample supply of roots and vegetables during the past season for their requirements.

There are 105 pupils enrolled at this school. Recreation is provided for them. I noted a good skating rink as well as a toboggan slide. The school is a frame building. They have an ample supply of fire extinguishers placed at convenient points throughout the building. A night-watchman makes hourly rounds and a record is kept of his visits to each station during the night.

I have already reported in a separate letter on the water situation at this school, and it is not necessary to repeat my remarks in this report.

Conditions at this school as I found them are very satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I visited the above named school on January 14th and made a general inspection of the building and the classrooms.

I found the building kept in a very clean and tidy condition. The Reverend Father Allard, O.M.I., is the Principal. He is assisted by a competent staff. The care of the building and pupils is in charge of the Sisters of the Assumption. They are very thorough and competent in the discharge of their respective duties. The children presented a healthy and well nourished appearance. The health of the children at this school has been remarkably good during the present winter.

A farm is now being operated. Last season their crop consisted of 2,800 bushels of oats and 600 bushels of wheat. A half section of land has been rented on the Battle River for summer pasturage. In addition to the land farmed on the school property, the Principal rents land in the neighborhood for the purpose of growing green feed for the stock.

The livestock consists of 27 head of cattle and 4 work horses. They have 17 cows regularly milking. The children are given all the milk they care to drink. They have in addition 25 hogs and have been able to provide their own beef and pork requirements. The poultry consists of 80 fowl.

They grew an ample supply of roots and vegetables during the past season for their requirements.

There are 105 pupils enrolled at this school. Recreation is provided for them. I noted a good skating rink as well as a toboggan slide. The school is a frame building. They have an ample supply of fire extinguishers placed at convenient points throughout the building. A night-watchman makes hourly rounds and a record is kept of his visits to each station during the night.

I have already reported in a separate letter on the water situation at this school, and it is not necessary to repeat my remarks in this report.

Conditions at this school as I found them are very satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

Dear Doctor McGill:-

Referring to your letter No. 105-1-5, dated the 17th ultimo, in regard to the water supply at the Thunderchild Residential School, I beg to advise you that I visited this school on the 14th instant and when there made careful enquiry into the whole situation.

As stated by you the water supply is now being obtained from the Canadian National Railway's tank at Delmas, the source of supply being a pipe-line to the Saskatchewan River. It is necessary in connection with this system to operate an engine and pump at the River, and the services of a man to take care of this unit are necessary. The Railway Company furnish the coal for the purpose of heating the station at the River and the water tank at Delmas. The School is paying all the expenses of operating the unit. I am informed by the Reverend Principal that the Railway Company, when handing over this unit to him, stated they would only take water from this tank in cases of emergency and would not use it as a regular source of water supply. Apparently this arrangement has not been carried out, in as much as the Reverend Principal states that practically all trains stop at Delmas and take water, and this necessitates a great deal of extra pumping and expense. The water is by no means pure and the system apart from this is expensive and unsatisfactory.

The water supply obtained generally in Delmas and by the white farmers in that area is procured at a depth of 32 feet where there is a seam of quick sand. During wet seasons this seam of sand was saturated with water and a fair supply was obtained, but of recent years owing to continuous lack of moisture the supply of water in this seam is limited and is becoming less as time goes on. I could hear of no instances where water had been obtained in this locality in deep wells.

- I also enquired into -

H. W. McGill, Esq., M.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
I also enquired into the question of the spring referred to in your letter. This spring is situated about 8,000 feet from the school in a north-westerly direction. The spring is a splendid one. I believe there is water enough flowing from the spring to fill a 10" pipe and the quality of the water is excellent. The spring itself is 80 feet below the level of the school, but the surface level of the ground above the spring would be about 40 feet below the level of the school. The spring is on the farm of a man named LeVallee and in order to reach it it would be necessary to run the ditch across the farm of Mrs. Duville. The Reverend Principal states that she has no objection to running such a ditch. He also stated that Mr. LeVallee would give the use of the spring free of cost on condition that the Department would pipe the water into his house, a distance of about 75 feet.

The only equipment required in order to tap this spring would be the necessary piping from the school to the spring, and my suggestion would be to place the pump house on the high ground at the top of the ravine and dig a well to tap the spring. The necessary storage water tanks are installed at the school. They have a suitable engine and also a wind-mill. I am satisfied that if we were permitted to get this work done on a competitive basis, the outlay necessary to complete the installation should not reach $10,000.00. This should be the outside cost and it could probably be done for a great deal less. The soil between the school and the location of the spring is a sandy loam, free from stones, which would make the digging of the ditch a comparatively easy matter. I looked over the ground and it is fairly level and is not rolling. There may be the odd hollow which would not offer any difficulty.

From what I could gather when on the ground, I feel that it would not be advisable to endeavor to obtain a water supply at this institution by sinking a well and the cost of obtaining water from this spring would in the end be more economical. There is no doubt in my mind but that a more than ample supply of water can be obtained from the spring and such an installation would be permanent. I have been visiting this school for over fourteen years and it is strange that the existence of this spring was never brought to my attention until now. Had it been, I would surely have reported in connection with it. I was advised -
it. I was advised that in the early days of the school a good supply of water was obtained in a shallow well, and I had the idea that possibly this seam might be tapped by a large dug well. However I now find that the Railway Company had the same idea and carried it into effect, but they found that the seam did not furnish sufficient water for their requirements and they therefore laid their pipe-line to the River.

The only suggestion I can make is that the school will have to carry on with the present arrangement until such time as funds might become available. I would again state however that I do not think it would be advisable to spend any more money in endeavoring to obtain a water supply by sinking a well in view of the information that I was able to gather.

Yours very truly,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

Sewage Disposal for Rural Homes in Saskatchewan

INTRODUCTION

Many rural residences are now equipped with electric light and power and all the labor-saving devices and conveniences which were at one time thought to be available only for the urban population. There has, however, been a tendency to postpone the installation of modern plumbing fixtures pertaining to sewage disposal. This bulletin provides information on the type of sewage disposal system best suited to the local conditions.

Experience has shown that a system of sewage disposal which could be left to run itself on a farm in the eastern provinces will not prove satisfactory when installed in Saskatchewan. The soil in much of the greater part is stiff, non-absorbent clay, where creeks or watercourses are almost unknown and where the frost can be relied upon to penetrate six feet deep.

In the "Plumbing and Drainage Regulations" issued under The Public Health Act reference is made to the construction of sewage disposal systems for isolated buildings.

It is with a view to supplementing these regulations and to removing the repeated requests for information regarding the proper method of constructing and operating a sewage disposal plant for a rural home on the prairie that this bulletin has been prepared.

In order that the information which follows may be a true statement of experience in constructing and operating sewage disposal plants in Saskatchewan, an investigation was made by officials of the Department of Public Health of the systems of sewage disposal actually used in 17 farms in different parts of the province.

The conclusions arrived at as a result of this investigation are embodied in the following pages and in the revised drainage and plumbing regulations.

SEWAGE TREATMENT

Sewage from a farm house, that is, the waste water from water closets, baths, sinks and wash tubs, may be disposed of in one of three ways:

(1) By discharge into a watercourse; (2) by discharge into the subsoil; (3) by discharge on the ground surface.

Necessity for Treatment.

Each of these methods of disposal requires some form of preliminary treatment to remove a proportion of the solids, otherwise a serious nuisance will be created.

Cesspools.

The cesspool is an attempt to combine treatment and disposal of the sewage and it accomplishes neither. A cesspool, as one usually finds it, consists of a covered pit, the ground on the sides being either of brick, wood or concrete. It is not a well, but with nothing but water for a bottom, the purpose being to allow the liquids to soak away into the ground.

The solids in the sewage settle to the bottom of the cesspool and choke any porous soil in the immediate vicinity, absorption and the cesspool quickly becomes stagnant and offensive. The construction of cesspools as above described is no longer authorized by the regulations issued under The Public Health Act.

Septic Tanks.

The septic tank is the simplest and most practical form of treatment to reduce the suspended matter and to render the sewage capable of final disposal with the minimum of nuisance.
What the Septic Tank does.

The function of the septic tank is to assist and to expedite the natural processes of decomposition and purification.

Two simple changes take place in such a tank:

1. The first is the settlement of the solids to the bottom, the grease and lighter particles floating to the top.

2. The second is the rotting of the settled solids.

This is brought about by the action of a certain type of bacteria which multiply in the solids and in the scum which forms on the surface of the tank.

These bacteria thrive without oxygen and break up the solids into liquids and gases which are then discharged from the tank.

The statement has often been made that sewage after passing through a septic tank has undergone a "ninety per cent" purification and responsible citizens have averred that the effluent from a septic tank should be fit to drink.

Let these illusions once and for all dispelled.

The effluent from a septic tank is just as dangerous to health as the raw sewage which is discharged from the house.

A septic tank removes the greater part of the solids from the sewage, but it does not destroy or remove any disease organisms which may be present in the sewage as it enters the tank.

Nor is the effluent free from offence. If allowed to pond on the surface of the ground it will create a nuisance.

A septic tank will not continue to operate indefinitely without attention.

Although the purpose of the tank is to liquefy the solids, a certain amount of solid matter and residue will accumulate in the tank and will require removal once or twice yearly.

Location of Septic Tank.

The excavation necessary for the tank may be greatly reduced if advantage is taken of any fall which there may be in the ground surface.

The soil pipe should be led from the house at the point nearest to the site of the tank.

Too frequently the plumbing is completed without any consideration being given to the position of the tank and disposal area, resulting in the latter being sited to suit the soil pipe.

In view of the low temperatures of our winter it is necessary to consider every means by which the contents of the tank may be protected against frost and for this reason the septic tank may in some cases be constructed close to the house. (See figures 3 and 4.)

The basement or foundation wall of the house must under no circumstance be used as a wall for the tank, behind the tank wall, if it has a minimum thickness of 9 inches of concrete, may be built against the tank wall.

In such cases every precaution must be taken to make the tank absolutely watertight.

The inside of the tank should be finished with a coating of cement mortar in the proportion of 1 of cement to 1 of sand.

The tank should not be situated under a window or near to a door.

Construction of Septic Tank.

The dimensions of the septic tank should be 6 feet 6 inches in length by 3 feet in breadth by 4 feet in depth. (See figure 5.)

This size of tank should be used in all installations for 12 persons or under.

For larger installations the capacity of the tank should be equal to 24 hours flow of sewage estimating the latter at 30 gallons per head per day.

The depth of the tank below water level should never be less than 4 feet.

The width of the tank should be in the direction of flow and should be about one and one-half times the width to give uniform flow through the tank and to ensure that the outlet is reasonably distant from the agitation caused at the inlet.

The inlet to the tank should be baffled by discharging the sewage through a T pipe which should extend into the tank about 18 inches.

The effluent from the tank should be drawn off at a similar depth below the surface, through a T pipe to prevent the discharge of any scum.

The gases which are formed by the bacterial action in the tank escape through the inlet T piece along the inlet pipe and through the soil pipe to the root of the house.

An air vent must be provided for the tank. This should be a concrete slab with cap or manhole cover and frame of sufficient size to permit of the tank being inspected and cleaned out.

Wrought iron steps let in to the wall of the tank should be placed immediately below the manhole.

FINAL DISPOSAL OF THE EFFLUENT

Three methods of disposal have been referred to and these will be discussed separately.

DISCHARGE OF EFFLUENT INTO A WATERCOURSE

The surface water supplies of Saskatchewan are very limited and they are all liable to be used as sources of domestic water supply.

It is contrary to the provisions of The Public Health Act to discharge any liquid waste, including the effluent from a septic tank, into a stream, river or lake, unless a certificate has been issued by the Minister of Public Health authorizing the effluent in question may be discharged without injury or risk to public health.

Such a certificate would, generally speaking, be granted subject to the construction of filters or some form of secondary treatment which would render the effluent free from offence.

Any person contemplating sewage disposal by this method should communicate with the Department of Public Health when a special investigation will be made of the circumstances.

DISCHARGE OF EFFLUENT INTO THE SUBSOIL

This method is the most common form of disposal of a septic tank effluent. It is applicable only to a limited quantity of liquid, such as that represented by the flow from a residence of average size.

Its success depends almost entirely on the porosity of the ground.

The subsoil throughout the greater part of this province is a non-absorbent clay, and in view of adoption of this method of disposal in Saskatchewan must therefore be attended by regulations.

The discharge of sewage or of a septic tank effluent into the subsoil within the limits of any city, town or village where sewerage is carried away by means of regular sewers, contrary to The Public Health Act, under the written authority of the Minister of Public Health has been obtained.

The Use of an Absorption Field.

The effluent from the septic tank overflows into a "doubling" or syphon chamber which gradually fills to a certain level and discharges its contents at intervals by means of an automatic syphon into a series of open-jointed field tiles laid under the surface of the ground.

The liquid is thus gradually absorbed by the subsoil or soaks through to the underlying strata.

It must be obvious that if the ground is not porous, that is, if there are no indications of drainage, or if it is already waterlogged, this means of disposal cannot be adopted with success.

It has frequently been asserted that a clay subsoil may be made to absorb a septic tank effluent by placing the tile pipes in a bed of broken stone or other coarse material.
Statements like this are entirely misleading.

The ground is sandy and will absorb a certain amount of liquid. Its capacity to absorb the effluent may certainly be increased by surrounding the tile pipes with broken stones or gravel. But if a 6-inch diameter hole drilled in the clay is filled with stones or gravel, and if it is made so that the water can flow through it, it would be futile to enlarge the hole to 18 inches diameter and to line it with stones as a means of making the water soak into the ground. The effect would simply be to increase the capacity of the hole for holding water.

Similarly the construction of an artificial absorption bed in a clay subsoil is equivalent to providing a reservoir to hold the sewage and will serve as a matter of time until the trench becomes waterlogged and sewage backs up into the septic tank.

Underground Filtration.

In other parts of the Dominion where nature has been more generous with her waterways, the system of subsurface distribution is used extensively in conjunction with a surface outlet for the effluent.

In some cases the field is not underdrained and the subsoil is used as a filter instead of an absorptive bed. The septic tank effluent after filtering through a few feet of sand or gravel is collected by underground pipes and distributed in the subsoil. The soil oxidizes the sewage before discharge and an indifferent effluent is discharged into a watercourse or on the ground surface.

Unfortunately this method is incapable of general application in this province, owing to the difficulty of obtaining a surface outlet.

Absorption Field systems in Clay Subsoil

The treatment and the disposal of a septic tank effluent are two distinct and separate problems which must not be confused.

The treatment involves the action of the purifying bacteria in the soil does not present a problem of disposing of several hundreds of gallons of liquid daily.

This is the real difficulty which presents itself on the prairie—the disposal of the treated effluent—and in the absence of a porous subsoil it is only throwing time and money away to construct an absorption field.

Design of Syphon Chamber.

If the ground is suitable for an absorption field a syphon chamber should be built to discharge the effluent on the bed intermittently.

The syphon chamber should be constructed along with, and should form a second chamber of the septic tank. (See figure 1.)

The capacity of the syphon chamber should be such as to cause the field to be flushed about three times in the twenty-four hours.

Taking the daily flow of 200 gallons this would mean a flushing capacity in the syphon chamber of 600 gallons or 10 cubic feet, or a chamber 2 feet long, by 3 feet wide, by 17 inches deep.

A syphon chamber of these dimensions will be suitable for systems constructed for 12 persons or under.

The action of the automatic syphon which does the sewage on to the field is as follows:

The U trap is filled with water and as the sewage flows into the syphon chamber air is introduced into the bell which covers the long leg of the U.

The sewage is prevented from discharging by the weight of the liquid in the short leg of the syphon. When the surface of the sewage level has fallen enough in the syphon chamber the air pressure forces the end of the syphon over and the pressure of the air contained in the short leg and part of the sewage in the latter is forced out.

This starts the full flow through the syphon which continues until the sewage in the syphon chamber falls to the under side of the bell when air is again admitted, the pressures are equalized and the flow ceases.

An overflow pipe from the syphon chamber is necessary in case the syphon should fail at any time. This overflow also acts as a vent pipe to provide air for the syphon. Vent holes should also be left in the wall which divides the septic tank from the syphon chamber, if this wall is raised up to the level of the drain main. A manhole similar to those specified for the septic tank should be set in the cover of the syphon chamber, and specified size iron steps may be provided to facilitate inspection.

Construction of an Absorption Field.

If the effluent were to be discharged into the subsoil directly it left the tank, the ground surrounding the house would be fouled.

A fire-clay pipe with tight joints should therefore be laid with a fall of 1 in 100 from the syphon chamber to a point at least 25 feet from the house where a distribution chamber of sufficient size is constructed.

From this manhole the effluent is run through open-jointed tiles and absorbed by the ground. (See figures 1 and 2.)

As a general rule 50 feet of field tile should be provided for each person in the house or 100 feet for a household of six.

In silty soils or sand or gravel the amount of tile per person may be reduced to 40 or even 30 linear feet.

The lines of tile should be laid 4 feet apart with a fall of about 3 inches in 100 feet.

The field may be conveniently excavated by means of a trench and corner.

Open tile drains should be laid on and surrounded by a 6-inch layer of broken stone, brick, or gravel to prevent clogging during the absorption process and to prevent the entrance of sand or earth at the open joint of the pipes. If gravel is available loose the stones should be covered to advantage with a nine-inch layer before the tile is placed in position.

Care must be taken in backfilling the excavation, in order that the pipes and their surrounding bed be not disturbed.

Trees or bushes should not be grown over absorption beds as the roots may penetrate the openings between the tiles and obstruct the flow of sewage.

Depth of Tank and Absorption Field Below Ground.

The changes in the provincial plumbing and drainage regulations which has hitherto required all lateral sewers to be laid has been amended with the issue of this bulletin, and drainage of basements will in future be optional.

Any additional expense incurred by draining the basement is justified, however, by the sanitary advantages obtained, and it is recommended that basement drainage be provided in all cases.

Where there is a good surface fall available the field tiles may, subject to the conditions stated above, be laid on the surface. Where full advantage may be taken of the action of the soil bacteria, namely 16 to 20 inches below the surface.

Rolling ground is, however, the exception rather than the rule in this province and in the average instance it will be found that the field tile must of necessity be laid at least three or four feet below ground level.

The regulations which have hitherto governed the installation of septic tanks in this province required all absorbent systems to be constructed at a depth which would prevent them being frozen or seven feet below the ground surface.

While the deep system is the only one which this department can guarantee against failure during the winter months, investigation has shown that septic tanks and absorbent fields may be operated at shallow depths if certain requirements are rigidly observed.

These requirements are as follows:

(1) The absorbent field, whether shallow or deep, must be constructed in ground which will absorb water. The more absorbent the soil, the less danger there is of the field freezing.
The surface of the liquid in the septic tank must not be higher than the original ground level. In instances where connection has been brought from the house above the ground line, in an effort to provide a shallow absorption field, the practice has invariably been accompanied by the freezing of the liquid in the tank.

The septic tank and all pipe lines, manholes and field tiles must be covered with a layer of dirt or concrete set in thin slabs during the winter months.

The tank and absorption field must be kept in continuous use throughout the winter. If the house is left vacant for a few days the system will freeze and be rendered useless until the frost goes out of the ground.

**DISCHARGE OF EFFLUENT ON THE GROUND SURFACE**

When the ground is incapable of absorbing liquid, the only practicable system of disposal is to pump the effluent from the septic tank and remove it to some distant point where it may be discharged on the ground without giving offence.

**Sewage Pump Well.**

The effluent from the septic tank should flow into a pump well which is designed to hold at least one week's flow of sewage. (See Figures 3 and 4 and accompanying table.)

In a household of six the minimum capacity of the pump well would be 1200 or 1360 gallons, or a tank 6 feet by 6 feet by 6 feet deep.

The liquid may be pumped from the tank by hand or by power as desired.

In towns and villages the owner should provide a tank-wagon and undertake the regular pumping of the sewage effluent.

In rural districts the effluent should be discharged on the ground at a point as far removed from the house as practicable and in no case nearer to the house than 100 feet.

During the winter months this distance should be considerably increased for the frozen effluent will accumulate on the ground and cause a serious nuisance when the frost goes.

A planting of trees or shrub with good surface drainage makes a suitable area on which to discharge the effluent.

**Location of Sewage Pump Well.**

The sewage pump well and septic tank should be situated at least 50 feet from the house.

The drain from the house to the tank should be four inch vitrified pipe with cement mortar joints laid carefully at a grade of 1 in 40 or a fall of approximately ¼ of an inch to the foot.

**Vegetable Gardens.**

The question has often been asked "Is it safe to eat vegetables which have been grown on soil irrigated by a septic tank effluent?"

It is only safe if the vegetables have been cooked.

Vegetables which are eaten raw such as radish and lettuce should not be grown on areas which may receive a sewage effluent.

**Distance of Sewage Pump Well and Absorption Field From Water Supply**

It is impracticable to state any minimum distance from an underground water supply at which it is safe to discharge sewage on or into the soil.

The sewage disposal system and the well should be as far removed from each other as possible and in no case should a septic tank effluent be discharged on or into the ground within 100 feet of a well or other water supply.

---

**OPERATION INSTRUCTIONS**

**Septic Tank.**

The scum which gathers on the surface of the tank should not be disturbed unless it exceeds 12 inches in depth, when part of it should be removed.

The scum, by excluding light and air from the liquid, provides the conditions under which anaerobic organisms multiply on its under surface and in the solids which settle to the bottom of the tank.

When the solids in the base of the tank reached a depth of 18 inches they should be removed and ploughed into the ground.

This will necessitate pumping out the tank once or at the most twice yearly.

NOTE: It regular yearly attention is not given to the cleaning of the tank, the accumulation of sludge will become so great that the work of removing it becomes dangerous. Any person who is required to enter a septic tank for the purpose of removing sludge, should have a rope attached to him and there should be two men on the ground surface at all times present.

Before starting the system the syphon must be filled with water. The manhole cover on the syphon chamber should be lifted occasionally and the action of the syphon examined.

If the flush is not acting properly the bell of the syphon should be removed, the syphon filled with water and the bell replaced.

**Sewage Pump Well.**

A float with indicating rod projecting through the roof of the pump well can easily be arranged to show when the well requires emptying.

The float should be arranged to rise higher than a level which is six inches below the overflow pipe of the septic tank.

Any solids or scum which may be present in the pump well should be removed when the septic tank is being cleaned out.

Care should be taken to prevent fouling of the ground below the pump discharge. A watertight chute or pipe should be used to convey the liquid to the wagon or to the point at which it is discharged on the ground.

**Absorption Field.**

The cover on the distributing manhole should be lifted at regular intervals and the operation of the system noted.

**Protection Against Frost.**

Not later than October 1 of each year all pipe lines, field tiles, manholes and tanks which are less than seven feet below the surface should be covered with a layer of damp pressed straw 12 inches thick.

This layer should extend 4 feet on each side of tanks and pipes.

Manure must not be used for this purpose; not only is it insanitary but it will not protect the ground sufficiently against frost.

**GENERAL CONCLUSIONS**

The conclusions arrived at from a study of the information embodied in the foregoing pages may be stated briefly as follows:

1. The cesspool is an obsolete and unsatisfactory method of sewage treatment or disposal. The construction and cesspool is contrary to law.

2. No matter what means of final disposal of the effluent are adopted, a septic tank should be built wherever there is the treatment of sewage, where there is no connection to a public sewer.

Each time you were kind enough to visit our school, you had the opportunity to see by yourself its scantiness for the number of children accommodated therein. I did realize it myself as soon as I took charge as Principal, and it already appeared to me that such a state could not subsist any longer - that two halls, (12' x 32' x 9') could not be suitable refectories for 120 children. That dormitories where children are packed two by two are neither hygienic nor decent, That a school like ours, must be granted with an infirmary so that, in case of serious illness or mortality, the dormitories would not be used in its stead.

Naturally my first thought was to beg the Department of Indian Affairs for a new addition to the house. But as you are well aware, dear Mister Murison, there was also the "Water Question" and I felt that this one should come first.

Last winter, as the Department had already gone to some expense to provide us with a water supply, and as it would cost still more to make of it a success, and, as on the other hand, it pained me to see the children every day in such an uncomfortable state, I ventured to begin by myself the much desired enlargement. During two weeks I lived the lumberman's life, in shanties, a hundred miles away, to have logs cut and 21,000 feet of lumber sawed. With this lumber, piled and dried during the summer, I undertook, in September, a two story addition, 18' x 40', which I have just completed.

This new construction, as you may ascertain during your forthcoming visit, which, we hope, will be soon, provides more ample space for refectories and dormitories and suitable accommodation for an infirmary.

Such is my case, and although the wood work and lumber did not exceed my estimates, these were found to be short for the plumbing and steamfitting. Mr. Minister,

On November 8 last, I requested Mr. W. Murison, Inspector of Saskatchewan Indian Reserves, to kindly endeavour obtaining from the Department some financial assistance which was urgently needed to meet part of the expenditures incurred for most urgent repairs to our school.

I was advised by Mr. Murison in his reply of January 7 of the Department's refusal and the reasons therefor. I had anticipated these reasons, Sir, and I was under the impression that I had dealt with them sufficiently in my letter of November 8, by showing the urgent nature of such repairs and the great sacrifices we had to make to reduce their cost. The purpose of this letter, however, is not to criticize the Departmental decision, but to ask for your help in some other repairs which are actually urgent and which we cannot undertake ourselves and which might leave the Department open to rather violent criticisms by the Indians.

On several occasions I have called the Departmental Agents' attention to the lack of a proper infirmary. Our refectories and dormitories are too small and a large number of our pupils have to sleep two in a bed. This is the reason why I caused an addition to be built to the old building in the hope that the Department would agree to dividing the expenses. Unfortunately, such an addition has not provided for beds, mattresses, pillows and sheets for which we have no money available. So that in spite of the sacrifices we have imposed on ourselves, our pupils still have to sleep two in a bed, which is neither hygienic nor moral.

With respect to our water supply the Department is in possession of several letters from Mr. Macdonald, your agent, and Mr. Murison, your Inspector, Dr. Norquay and myself, in which we outlined the lack of proper water facilities for our schools. The drinking water given to our pupils is pumped directly from the Saskatchewan River by the Canadian National Railway and is not fit for consumption, and which, undoubtedly, would be condemned by any health inspector. It is to be feared that should there occur any serious diseases or deaths, an investigation would have to be held.
Another impending source of trouble, Sir, is the lack of proper fire protection. The two outside staircases of our school are more in the nature of fire traps than fire escapes. They are built of wood and so old that we will not use them even for fire drills. If a fire should occur during the night, there would probably be losses of lives.

Some two years ago, when Dr. McGill, Superintendent of Indian Affairs, visited us, I drew his attention to the matter. He had promised me at the time to see to it that the conditions be improved, but nothing has been done so far. I wish hereby to withdraw my responsibility in that connection.

We are also in great need of some house where we could give shelter to the Indians coming to visit their children. The shack now in use for that purpose is not fit for human beings, particularly during the winter. When the school was founded, such a need was not so pressing since most of the reserves were situated close by. Since, however, these reserves have been sold and the Indians are now living 50 to 60 miles and even 70 miles from here, that they must stay two or three days when they come.

It is true, Sir, that the Delmas Indian school is the property of the church. This is always the argument when we ask for assistance, but to my mind, this should not be a reason wherefor the Department should refuse assistance and the Indians of our reserves should meet with the same treatment as those of other localities. Very much to the contrary, the church has been able to build a school and keep it at the cost of great sacrifices when the pupils were few and the reserves at close vicinity, thus relieving the Department of an enormous burden, is it not somewhat the Department's duty to show them more generosity towards the school now that circumstances have changed, that Indians realize better the importance of instruction, that recruiting is more expensive and that the church can no longer support the charge. Your representatives at Battleford and Regina will tell you that we have done nothing to meet the situation and that we have made great sacrifices to keep this school going. May I hope, Sir, that you will give this letter your kind consideration and share in meeting the expenditures caused by these improvements which will facilitate the functioning of the school and give no ground to criticism.

(Complimentary closing)

MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General

I have your memorandum of the 21st instant, enclosing letter received from the Principal of the Thundershild Indian Residential School.

This school is, approximately, three-quarters of a mile from Delmas, Sask. It is conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, the Principal being Rev. J. H. O. Allard, O.M.I.

The Thundershild Residential School is owned by the Oblate Order and is a very old building. Last November, the Principal forwarded through Inspector Murison's office an account for $550.42, covering the cost of plumbing and radiation in an addition which the school authorities had recently built to the school. Due to the fact that the Department had not been consulted before the work was started and the further fact that there were no funds available in our appropriation for meeting this expenditure, the account was not paid. This explains the Principal's reference in the second paragraph of his letter of the 16th instant.

No request has been received for beds, mattresses, pillows and sheets mentioned in the third paragraph of the letter. Funds for these could be obtained from our appropriation this year if you wish to supply them. I am inclined to feel that they are required, in view of the fact that the school authorities
The Honourable the Superintendent General

built a new addition to the school last year, as mentioned above.

The water supply at this school has been a cause of considerable concern for some time past. At the present time, and for the past few years, the school has been obtaining their water from the Canadian Pacific Railway, who pump water to Delmas for the use of their engines. At one time, Delmas was a fairly large railway centre but, about two years ago, the Canadian Pacific Railway curtailed their work at this point and, as a consequence, were not so anxious to pump water as they did not have any great use for it. However, this was taken up with the railway authorities and the previous arrangements with the Thunderchild Residential School for supplying water were continued. The school has complained on several occasions of the cost to them of this system of obtaining water. There is no doubt that they are justified in this regard but, at the same time, it appears impossible to obtain water from wells. In 1934, the Department expended a very large sum of money in an endeavour to find water but, although one or two wells were dug to a considerable depth, no water was obtained. It has been reported that an adequate supply of water can be obtained from a spring but this would involve an expenditure of at least $10,000. The Department has not given any consideration to this latter proposal due to the lack of funds and the additional fact that, if at any time it was decided to replace the old building by a new building, the location of the school would probably be changed.

No recent request has been received; nor have any funds been provided, for fire escapes or a house to shelter Indians coming to the school to visit their children. The fire hazard at this school has been recognized for some time and an allowance is made for a night watchman's services during the period November 1st to April 30th, each year.

I return the original unsigned letter received by you, also a translation. A copy of this letter was forwarded direct to the Department and was signed by the Principal, Rev. J.H.O. Allard.

Mr. Minister,

On November 2 last, I requested Mr. W. Murison,
Inspector of Saskatchewan Indian Reserves, to kindly endeavour
obtaining from the Department some financial assistance which
was urgently needed to meet part of the expenditures incurred
for most urgent repairs to our school.

I was advised by Mr. Murison in his reply of
January 7 of the Department's refusal and the reasons therefor.
I had anticipated those reasons, Sir, and I was under the impression
that I had dealt with them sufficiently in my letter of November
2, by showing the urgent nature of such repairs and the great sacrifices
we had to make to reduce their cost. The purpose of this letter,
however, is not to criticize the Departmental decision, but to ask
for your help in some other repairs which are actually urgent and
which we cannot undertake ourselves and which might leave the Department
opened to rather violent criticisms by the Indians.

On several occasions I have called the Departmental
Agents' attention to the lack of a proper infirmary. Our
refectories and dormitories are too small and a large number of our
pupils have to sleep two in a bed. This is the reason why I
caused an addition to be built to the old building in the hope that the
Department would agree to dividing the expenses. Unfortunately, such
an addition has not provided for beds, mattresses, pillows and sheets
for which we have no money available. So that in spite of the
sacrifices we have imposed to ourselves, our pupils still have to sleep
two in a bed, which is neither hygienic nor moral.

With respect to our water supply the Department is
in possession of several letters from Mr. Macdonald, your agent,
and Mr. Murison, your Inspector, Dr. Norquay and myself, in
which we outlined the lack of proper water facilities for
our schools. The drinking water given to our pupils is pumped
directly from the Saskatchewan River by the Canadian National Railway
and is not fit for consumption, and which, undoubtedly, would be condemned by any health inspector. It is to be feared that should there occur any serious diseases or deaths, an investigation would have to be held.

Another impending source of trouble, Sir, is the lack of proper fire protection. The two outside staircases of our school are more in the nature of fire traps than fire escapes. They are built of wood and so old that we will not use them even for fire drills. If a fire should occur during the night, there would probably be losses of lives. Some two years ago, when Dr. McGill, Superintendent of Indian Affairs, visited us, I drew his attention to the matter. He had promised me at the time to see to it that the conditions be improved, but nothing has been done so far. I wish hereby to withdraw my responsibility in that connection.

We are also in great need of some house where we could give shelter to the Indians coming to visit their children. The shack now in use for that purpose is not fit for human beings, particularly during the winter. When the school was founded, such a need was not so pressing since most of the Reserves were situated close by. Since, however, those reserves have been sold and the Indians are now living 50 to 60 miles and even 70 miles from here, that they must stay two or three days when they come.

It is true, Sir, that the Delmas Indian school is the property of the church. This is always the argument when we ask for assistance, but to my mind, this should not be a reason wherefor the Department should refuse assistance and the Indians of our reserves should meet with the same treatment as those of other localities. Very much to the contrary, if the church has been able to build a school and keep it at the cost of great sacrifices when the pupils were few and the reserves at close vicinity, thus relieving the Department of an onerous burden, is it not somewhat the Department's duty to show them more generosity towards the school now that circumstances have changed, that Indians realize better the importance of instruction, that recruiting is more expensive and that the church can no longer support the charge. Your representatives at Battleford and Regina will tell you that we have spared nothing to meet the situation and that we have made great sacrifices to keep this school going. May I hope, Sir, that you will give this letter your kind consideration and share in meeting the expenditures caused by these improvements which will facilitate the functioning of the school and give no ground to criticism.

(Complimentary closing)

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 105-1-5, dated the 1st instant, with reference to batteries for the Thunderchild Residential School, which was received in this office during my absence on holiday.

Upon receipt of this letter Miss Wylie at once wrote to the Indian Agent at Battleford, requesting him to advise me as to the condition of the batteries now in use and how long they had been in operation. The Clerk at the Battleford Agency replied to this letter stating that he understood that the present batteries are about six years old, but did not state their condition. Reverend Father Allard came personally to the office during my absence and informed Miss Wylie that he had had the batteries examined by an expert who stated that they might give out at any time. Father Allard during my absence obtained quotations from the Electric Equipment Limited, Saskatoon, and the Sterling Mills Limited who are Agents for the Lemery-Dennison Electric Limited.

The battery required is a 56 cell, 7 plate, 80 ampere hour battery. The Electric Equipment Company of Saskatoon submit a quotation of $410.00 and will give an allowance of $60.00 for the old batteries, bringing the net cost to $350.00, F.O.B. Battleford. The Lemery-Dennison Electric quote $324.30 F.O.B. Toronto. In their quotation they do not state what they will allow for the old batteries, but it is expected that they would allow about the same as the Electric Equipment.

The Reverend Principal favors the Electric Equipment in as much as he is assured of their interest and service in connection with the operation of the batteries. I am submitting the quotations received for your information and will await your decision before placing an order.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 8th instant, regarding the erection of a new residential school building at Battleford or North Battleford, to replace the present school at Delmas, Sask., known as the Thunderchild Indian Residential School, in the Battleford Indian agency.

With reference to this matter, I would say that the present building at Delmas is a church-owned institution, erected in 1900, and is of wooden construction. Alterations and improvements have been made from time to time, but the building is unsuitable, is badly arranged inside, and it would be a waste of money to remodel and make further repairs. Besides, there is a very considerable fire hazard and the water supply is inadequate. An effort was made two years ago to obtain a water supply by drilling a well, but the scheme had to be abandoned as no water could be obtained after drilling to a depth of over 700 ft.

There is nothing official on our files regarding the rebuilding of the school at or near

- Battleford
Battleford, but the matter has been discussed with the church officials during their visit to the Department, and they have urged the erection of a new building.

It is the opinion of all authorities concerned, viz.: the officials of the Department and the church authorities, that a new school building is needed, to replace the present old, unsuitable building at Delano, and that the proper location would be at or near Battleford. However, no funds are provided at the present time to acquire a site and erect the new building. If a new building is erected, it would require accommodation for 150 children. The cost would be in the vicinity of $130,000.00, plus cost of site.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit my report on a visit to the Battleford Agency.

DELMAS SCHOOL

This school is old and of wood construction. The children and staff are well protected by fire escapes except in one portion of the building. This is, I understand, a recent addition containing a dormitory on the second and staff sleeping quarters on the third floor. In case of fire starting in this part of the building the lives of the children in the dormitory would be endangered while there would be no escape for those on the third floor. Authority to rectify this has now been received.

The dormitories, kitchens, dining rooms etc. were scrupulously clean and neat. The children were all clean, well clothed and apparently well nourished. The staff are all deeply interested in their work and the children happy and contented.

To Philip Phelan,Esq.
Chief,Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that we had considerable trouble with our little electric Delco plant. This plant had been completely repaired and put in order last summer and I expected to have a good service from it all winter. Just before Christmas, it was again put out and we had no light for some days. I sent to Saskatoon an engineer to know about this deficiency. They said there that the plant was far too small for our requirements and that it would never give satisfaction; on the contrary, it would give trouble. In fact, we have at school 170 bulbs using 6750 watts per hour. Our plant can produce only 2500 watts per hour; it is easy to see that we cannot rely on this plant. Moreover, this plant is obsolete, being a 1918 model and we cannot even find repairs.

I had a correspondence with the Lister Diesel generating plants, and from their information, it is sure that we need a 4.5 Kilowatt-hour plant. They have this in stock, but they ask for $1294.00 for the complete plant. The school could not pay for this amount and I ask you if you could not spare $500.00 in our favor that we may buy this plant at once. The school would pay the balance up to $1294.00.

I did not ask for any money this year to be employed at school for improvement and I hope to obtain from you these $500.00.

An early and favorable reply will be much appreciated as we need badly another plant.

Yours truly,

Rev. Joseph Angin,
Principal.

Re. Indian School Delmas Electrical Alterations.

Dear Sir,

As requested by your office, I have made an inspection trip to the above mentioned Indian School at Delmas Sask., and carefully checked over the entire system of wiring in the School, and Barn, and outer buildings.

In the main school building, we have an overloaded condition existing with reference to the sub circuits, and the entire building is supplied by two circuits, in many of the rooms drop cord has been used, and installed behind and through wood work with no additional insulation provided, in one room I saw an electric plate of 600 watts connected to drop cord that has a capacity of only 300 watts, something similar to this occurs in the basement of the building in the wash room, where we have three washing machines operating at the same time, and supplied with drop cord and brass key sockets over a cement flooring.

In the Barns, Chicken House, Toilets, Summer Larder, Ironing Room, and Meat house, there is a decided lack of proper fusing of circuits, weatherproof solid wire has been used into these buildings, no strain insulators used on the outside to take care of the wind swing on the feed wires. The pole line from the Main building has not the proper spacing between wires, has been patched with rubber covered inside wiring which is not allowed, and the entire outdoor system is supplied by two wires only, which constitutes an overloaded condition.

In going from Room to Room in the Main building, I was constantly met with irregular practices of wiring, that will not let me patch up the system without a very considerable amount of rewiring, to bring this system up to anything like present day installations of safety from fire hazards. I might here make the suggestion that the control board from the Generator Plant in the Engine Room, be moved to a point of more accessibility in case of Fire, as it is now situated, where there to be a fire in this room, a person could disconnect the system without having to pass through the fire to reach the board. There are no sub-circuit fuse protections provided in the Engine Room, and the entire building is supplied by only two circuits inside.
I would suggest that the multifarious circuits running at all angles through out the grounds outside be overhauled and straightened up; we can use a great deal of the material already in service and a little new material added, also the outside circuits be grounded and protected from lightning. Also in the Main building that ceiling outlet boxes be installed behind the present outlets, and all splicing and taping be done in these boxes, at present there are no soldered joints, no rubber tape used on the splices throughout the entire system.

I have tabulated the materials I would require to make the necessary alterations to this system, and believe that it can be made very much neater, more efficient, and safer from fire hazard, also cut down a great deal on line losses, at a cost of $158.00 materials and labour supplied. We are fully qualified to make these alterations, being licensed and bonded in the Province and this City since 1929, and working at the trade since 1923. We can further guarantee a very decided improvement to the system if this step is taken by the Department.

Thanking you for the opportunity of making the inspection, and submitting an estimate to your office for this work, I trust we may be favoured by your considerations, I beg to remain,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 1st instant with reference to the electric wiring at the Thunderchild Indian residential school.

I note that the Potter Electric Shop quote a price of $1365.00 for material and labour. This appears rather high but it is quite possible that the electric wiring in this building is in bad condition.

I presume that the Principal of the school has also been informed of the report of the Saskatchewan Power Commission. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your file in connection with lighting system of the school and may say that I am not prepared to pay part of the expenses incurred, chiefly at the beginning of the financial year.

I am not under the impression that the lighting system be so defective as we have replaced completely the lighting motor with a Lister Diesel, and that we can now regulate the current very easily; with the Delco motor we had before, it was impossible to regulate the current.

On another hand, Mr. Inspector Robertson states that the school, in case of repairs to the lighting system, could not obtain any other improvement during the fiscal year. I know however that Ottawa asked for suggestions to have a shop built on the grounds of the school, and if even nothing is done in this connection, I would suggest that the money that has been appropriated for the Thunder child School be used for a better purpose, for instance, to supply an extractor and a washer for the laundry. The small Maytag machines we have for the laundry are far too small and light, and do not give satisfaction. The machines that could give satisfaction would be an extractor and a washer designed in the Stanley Brock Catalogue and that are in use in all the other Indian Schools.

Hoping this will meet with your approval, I remain,

Yours truly,

(Signed) Rev. Joseph Angin, O.M.I.,
Principal

The Joint Standing Committee on Education has received a report from the Minister of Indian Affairs regarding the status of residential schools in Canada.

The report states that the federal government has committed $33 million over five years to address the legacy of residential schools. This includes funding for the National Centre for Truth and Reconciliation and the establishment of a Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

The report also highlights the importance of recognizing the contributions of Indigenous peoples to Canadian society, including their role in education. It calls for increased funding for Indigenous-led education programs and the implementation of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.

The report concludes by urging the federal government to take immediate action to address the legacy of residential schools and to ensure that Indigenous peoples have full access to quality education.
The Board concurs in the above report and recommendation, and submit the same for favorable consideration.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BATTLEFORD AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JULY 1939.

I wish to direct the attention of the department to the need of proper supervision at the Meadow Lake and Saulteaux and Moosomin Reserves. On these reserves, under proper supervision, community farming would succeed, but proper supervision is needed first. All the Indians of these three bands are anxious to farm and are making requests for horses for the purpose, but I do not think this, only, will solve their difficulties, as distributing horses about the reserves, with no supervision and no direction of their efforts would be useless. On these two reserves, as education is a problem, day schools, with the right kind of teachers, would be the best beginning, in my opinion. At the present time the Indians of these reserves are asking for farming instructors, but there are a number of children not being educated, and there is no school for them to attend. These children are the ones to whom we must look for the future of their reserves and education, along proper lines, on their own reserves, in daily contact with their parents and the other Indians of the reserve, would be beneficial for their future welfare, and contact with them, and with the right kind of teachers, would be beneficial to the parents, as well.

J.P.B. Ostrander.
Agent.

Dear Sirs,

As per your instructions I am pleased to quote on
the proposed Electric Wiring for Thunderchild Indian Residential School as follows:

All wiring shall be done in accordance with the Saskatchewan Power Commission regulations.

All wiring shall be enclosed in approved steel conduit and properly fastened to walls and ceiling.

All circuits and branch circuits shall have both conductors protected by suitable fuses. In the case of circuit wired with #14 gauge wire, these fuses shall not exceed 15 amperes. All circuit wiring shall be done with identified conductors, preferably a white wire properly marked with a tracer, and a colored wire shall be used so that in the event of A.C. being available at some future date, the system could be easily changed to a single fuse solid neutral installation.

All basement lights must be equipped with approved weatherproof sockets, and controlled by suitable switches mounted on the wall in suitable conduit fittings.

Each distribution panel shall be fed from a suitable square "D" switch located in the basement directly below the risers feeding the lighting panels.

A connection shall be made direct from switchboard in basement to suitable square "D" switches to feed outlying buildings. This connection shall be made in such a way that no extra load will be placed on the wires feeding the branch circuit panels.

Dear Father Plourde:

Some months ago the authorities of the Hydro Electric Commission in Saskatchewan visited the Thunderchild Indian residential school and condemned the electric wiring. As you are aware this school is by no means fireproof and in view of the condition of the wiring as reported by the Hydro Electric Commission the Department considered that it was in the best interests of the pupils and the members of the staff to minimize the danger of fire by rewiring the whole building.

We obtained a very reasonable quotation on this work from Mr. M.A. Halliday of Battleford, Sask. One of the conditions on which he quoted us such a reasonable figure was that the school would supply the board for his men while he was working and also give him the assistance of one of the school staff without pay. The Department feels that this was a reasonable request and I was, therefore, very much surprised to hear from Inspector Robertson this morning that the Principal, Rev. Father Angin, refuses to allow any member of the staff to help Mr. Halliday unless this staff member is paid wages.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 22nd instant, No. 105-1-5, in connection with rewiring of the Thunderchild Indian Residential School, and account submitted for the amount of $1050.00 as voucher No. 463, I have to say that Mr. Holliday's claim that he has a right to add 5% to the original tender, is in the fact that, through delay in accepting his tender, approximately twelve weeks, with the declaration of war in the meantime, and the resulting increase of 8% in the cost of the material, to him, and his original tender was as low as was possible, and still meet the requirements of the inspector for the Provincial Power Commission.

The matter of deciding whether the 5% surcharge, is justified, is left to the Department to decide. I am making no recommendation in the matter, but the facts are as stated in Mr. Holliday's letter, enclosed herewith.

Regarding the complaint of the Principal, that the old fixtures were taken by Mr. Holliday, I have only to say that I have seen the material which was brought in by Mr. Holliday, at the suggestion of the electrician, who informed him that the inspector for the Power Commission would make objection if he found a lot of old wire and other materials on the job, when he came to inspect, and the material was brought in to Battleford and stored. The Principal claims that Mr. Holliday took lights and globes, which Mr. Holliday denies, but has agreed to send him six new ones without charge, to satisfy him. Please advise me as to the disposal of the old material which was brought in by Mr. Holliday. It might be worth $5.00 as junk.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In confirmation of our conversation of recent date regarding the Thunderchild Indian School, Delmas, on January 9th, 1940 we received a notification from the Electric Shop Limited, Lloydminster, notifying this Branch that the electrical installation of the residential school had been rewired. Upon an inspection being made of the premises a report was sent to the Electric Shop, form K No.4226. Copy of same is being attached for your information.

On August 5th, we received a letter from the Electric Shop Ltd., as follows:

"Regarding the changes necessary at the Thunderchild Indian School, Delmas, we have communicated with the contractor for whom we subbed this work and are still awaiting word from him or from the Indian Department. We might mention that the biggest item on your form K for this job, the two pump motors, were not included in the specifications of our contract with the Dept. and were not noticed until the rewiring had been completed and we were tearing down the old wire, when, rather than leave the school without water service we made a temporary hook-up and advised the school engineer to that effect before leaving. We can, of course, go to Delmas and cut off these motors but we do not wish to take such arbitrary action without hearing from them."

We advised the Electric Shop not to cut off the motors at the present time, as we were taking the matter up with the Department of Indian Affairs.
It would be greatly appreciated if you could assist us in any way regarding the wiring of the two pump motors, as the two motors will have to be wired in conduit, each motor to be on a separate circuit and controlled by enclosed externally operated switches.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Regarding the School Main Building not only an enlargement would be necessary. I consider that it would be urgent to replace the old building with a new one and the reason for this is.

The present building is 47 years old and has already been subject to several modifications and has been enlarged at five different times. It would be practically impossible to make another addition in a convenient and satisfactory manner.

The present condition of the house does not even give the comfort that reasonably could be expected. i.e. During winter, although the heating system is an excellent one we are badly protected against the cold which introduces itself through the dilapidated walls.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

I am enclosing a letter addressed to the Department by Reverend Father Cabana, O.M.I., the new Principal of the above school.

The list of requirements for this institution for the coming year is large but it has apparently been neglected and a large appropriation seems quite in order for the coming ESTIMATES.

In case the Principal's demand for a new school cannot be granted, I would suggest the construction, during the coming year, of a four-room class building which could form part of the new school set-up. As this building would only be used for class purposes, it need not be fire-proof and, therefore, could more easily be constructed and at less expense than a more elaborate building.

I am of the opinion that the next most needed improvement is in the laundry. This laundry is the most poorly equipped of any that I have seen in any Indian residential schools. There is no steam, no washing machine and wringer. The washing has to be done by hand with the exception of a few small Domestic machines which are completely inadequate for the large quantity of clothes in a residential school which has an enrollment of 120, with a staff in proportion. The coming estimates should provide for a steam boiler, a washing machine, a wringer and possibly a flat ironer. These machines would put the school on a basis parallel to most of the schools of the Department.

I already mentioned to you over the 'phone, the necessity of providing this school with a proper size cooking range and hot water tank.

The other items asked for are as necessary but particularly the bedsteads and mattresses. As far as kitchen equipment is

Honorable Sir,

The sad news must have reached you by now of the burning to ground of the Thunderchild Residential School at Delmas, on Jan. the 13th last. The Oblate Fathers have been in charge of this school from the start, and, as the Superior Provincial of said order, I am writing you today to request that you do everything possible to have this Residential School rebuilt at the earliest convenience.

I was in the vicinity when this total destruction occurred. The Principal and the good Sisters in charge of the upkeep and instruction in this school are not only in favor, but insist that the missionary work performed by them for so many years now, be continued. They are very anxious that a new school be rebuilt, in order that they may continue their missionary work amongst the Indians.

The Indian Chiefs, speaking in the name of the majority of the Indian population on their reserves, have come to me in order that I may ask the Indian Department for a boarding school. In fact, there is no doubt in anybody's mind around here, that only a Residential School can accommodate and give the necessary education to the widely scattered children of the Indian Reserves of Red Pheasant, Pundmaker, Sweet Grass, Meadow Lake and Waterhen.

I am therefore confident that the Department will decide and start shortly, as everybody expects, the construction of a fire proof residential school, where priest and sisters will continue their important work of education and instruction of this Indian youth.

I am writing you, Honorable Sir, with the hope that you will use your influence, which is strong, to the effect of obtaining a favorable decision in this matter, at the
coming session. All of us hope to see a new school built for our Indian children by next Fall.

Thanking you very kindly for the interest you will be taking in this important and vital matter for our Indians, I remain

Dear Mr Neary,
