Dron, of the Fire Commr.'s Office, Saskatoon, called at this office and suggested that the two Indian boys, Alfred Moosomin and Sandy Standinghorn referred to in para. 1 of Cutknife Det. report herein, dated the 21-1-48, should be interrogated in regards to their alleged threats to burn the school. On the 12th and 13th inst. patrol were therefore made to Red Pheasant and Sweetgrass Indian Reserves where the two boys were located and interrogated at length.

2. Alfred Moosomin admitted that he might have said that he was going to burn the school, but stated that so had some of the other boys who attended the school. He could recollect no names, but intimated that this was just idle talk and said just for fun. He stated that after the fire they had been lodged in another school building for the night and that after they had gone to bed Sandy Standinghorn, age 10 years, had told him that he had set the fire, that two older boys, Oliver Longneck and Ernest Bear, had given him a can of gasoline and some papers and forced him, under threats of a beating, to go and set the fire. He had then gone to the basement and set the fire in a cupboard. Alfred Moosomin, who is 14 years old, denied any implication in the setting of the fire.

3. Sandy Standinghorn admitted that he had threatened to burn, also that he had told Alfred Moosomin that he had burned the school, but that he had said this just for fun and that he did not think Alfred had believed him at the time. He went on to mention four other boys who had said that they were going to burn the school; these were Emil Longneck, Fred Moosomin, Robert Ahtyman and Evans Clay, all ranging in ages from 10 to 14 years of age.

4. It will be noted that each youngster interrogated in this connection names some other Indian boy who either has said that he set the fire or was going to set fire to the school. Apparently in the manner of boys that age they had boasted about having set the fire in order to gain attention and recognition from their school mates. All of those mentioned with the exception of Robert Ahtyman and Evans Clay have been interrogated either by the police or Mr. Dron. It is not considered that any useful purpose would be served in pursuing this matter any further at the present. Should any information considered to be of any value be forthcoming in the future, the necessary action will be taken.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Thunderchild Indian Residential School

You will recall that the above Residential School was recently destroyed by fire. It is understood that Father Plourde, Superintendent of the Indian Welfare and Training Commission of the Oblate Order, and Reverend Father Boucher, Oblate Provincial for Alberta and Saskatchewan, recently visited the Minister and discussed with him the establishment of a temporary residential school in the buildings now at Dalmas, Saskatchewan. These buildings were not destroyed when the main structure was burned.

We have now received a letter from the Reverend Father Plourde, reading as follows:

"It is our intention to continue to operate the above school and we have for this purpose the following buildings, all situated on the school ground or south boundary:

1) A brick house 30' x 30', two storeys and full basement. The attic, although not in use at the present time, can, with very little expense, be made into a dormitory. The building is hot air heated.

2) A frame house 20' x 24', two storeys and basement.

3) Garage 30' x 35', two storeys. This building will require a few windows and the walls must be winterized. This can be done with rough lumber and Ten Test.

4) Two very well built large granaries which may be used as sleeping quarters for some of the staff."
5) The house garage 20' x 20' can be converted into a laundry.

"To enable our Church authorities to carry on these plans, the following articles of furniture, bedding and laundry will be required:

1) 30 complete beds including mattresses, pillows, blankets, sheets, pillow cases, towels.

2) 30 desks, with class material.

3) Kitchen stove and utensils with refectory outfit.

4) Laundry equipment, which should include steam boiler, washing machine, dryer and wringer, and one small ironer.

5) Furthermore, the principal will need about 10,000' of building lumber and Ten Trestle, and ordinary building material such as nails, paper, etc.

"It is our purpose to provide at the present for 30 girls, and, if we find it possible later on, we shall add between 20 to 30 boys to the above number of children.

"I hope that you will be able to issue the necessary authority to proceed with the above plan."

We have been advised by Mr. Indian Agent Jones that we can obtain the beds, mattresses, blankets, pillows, folding tables and folding benches from the Provincial Government at Prince Albert. These supplies are available at War Assets Corporation prices. It is also understood that the other items are in fairly good supply. Therefore, authority is requested from the Minister for the following:

(a) the establishment of a temporary residential school with a pupilage of 30 to replace the former Thunderchild Residential School,

(b) the inclusion of $4,000.00 in the supplementary estimates to purchase the necessary supplies for the operation of this temporary school.

STATEMENT of Sister St. Joseph Edmond.

BEGINS: At about 7.05 P.M. of Jan. 13th when I went to the boys recreation room to give the names of the four boys I wanted at 7.30 P.M. for rehearsal I could not find Edwin TOOTOSIS. He was not at the rink where the other boys were skating, and did not come in till about 7.25 P.M. from outside. As soon as they were all in the classroom, boys and girls, I closed the door to begin to tell them about the rehearsal, when Sister St. Salomee ran by and called me, saying that there was fire in the basement. I immediately sent the children back to their respective recreation rooms and ran down to see what was to be done. In getting to the fire I crossed the whole basement. I passed the furnace, but saw everything was in order there. From this door I could see that the fire seemed to be in a cupboard on the north wall in which the men kept their tools. The inside of the cupboard was all in flames, and the flames were beginning to creep along the beams. I ran back to the laundry in the other room and began to fill pails with water, but the smoke prevented me from getting at the fire. The smoke was very dark and thick, and I had to get out into the open air to avoid choking. Just as I reached the top of the stairs I met Father Cabana, who had come from the rectory. I told him it was impossible to get down the stairs I had come up on, and he went down another stair to see the furnace. When I saw the flames in the cupboard there was too much smoke in that part to see everything. I could see that everything seemed alright in the engine-room, and that the motor was stopped. I couldn't see the fuel oil barrels, or the box with window panes, as the smoke was too dense. The other end of the room was clear, and I could see the work bench, and the mens toilet. ENDS.

1. At the request of Mr Dron, Investigator, Provincial Fire Commission Office, Edwin Tootoosis (Tr Ind) of Poundmaker Indian Reserve, late resident pupil of Delmas Residential School, was interviewed and the following signed statement was obtained:

Cut Knife, Sask Jan 20 '48

"I am 13 yrs of age. I have been going to Thunderchild Residential School, Delmas for the past eight years. I am in grade five. On the day of the fire (Jan 15th) after dinner, school started at one o'clock and was on till four. I was in school all the time. After school I skated until supper time, six o'clock. After supper I was skating again. I did not go into the basement of the school that day at all. The last time I was in the basement was when we hauled wood for the laundry. I think that was on Saturday, before the fire.

While I was skating the night of the fire, William Wright of Moosomin (Cochim) Reserve called me to go to the big classroom to practice for a play. I went right to the classroom. I had my sweater on but no coat. Sister St Joseph Edmond was in charge of the play and was in the classroom all the time. When the fire was reported I ran out and got my coat and cap and lined up outside with the boys. Then the sister sent me for the engineer who lived not far from the school. I went to his house and told him and came back with him. I then went to the ironing room and the children were warming themselves. This is a separate building. I then went with some other boys and helped the men save things from the south part of the school. Some of the children heard Alfred Moosomin (Red Pheasant or Stony Reserve) and Sandy Standinghorn of Sweetgrass Reserve, threaten to burn the school. This was about a month ago (after Alfred Moosomin was brought back when he ran away). This was after the sister had scolded him and he was mad. Sandy was a bad boy and got into lots of trouble. The children threatened to tell on these boys and they got scared.

Sgd Edwin Tootoosis".

Mr Dron requested interviewing this boy as he was alleged to have been smoking in the basement shortly before the fire and was alleged to be missing when the fire was in progress. His story covers his time before the fire and after the alarm.

This boy also stated that the principal permitted the boys to smoke and that this was the third school burned, while he, Father Cabana, was principal. One of the Sisters made the last assertion to Edwin Tootoosis."

STATEMENT of Father John B. CABANA:

BEGINS: I state I am the principal of Thunderchild Indian Residential School at Delmas, Sask. About 7:30 P.M. of Jan. 13th, 1948 the Sisters at the school phoned me at my residence and reported a fire in the basement of the school. I rushed over to the school, which is about 300 ft. from the residence and went into the basement right away. There was a lot of smoke in the basement and I couldn't get near the fire. The smoke smelled like oil smoke, and the fire at that time was burning in a cupboard on the north wall. This cupboard extended from the floor to the ceiling of the basement, and was used to store tools in. There was one barrel of diesel fuel, and one barrel of lubricating oil standing by the cupboard. Also there was two boxes of window panes, with straw and cut paper packing, standing next to the oil drums. The fire seemed to be coming from the cupboard. I left this room then and checked the furnace by an outside door, and found everything in order there. The light plant, which is in the basement was okay also. By that time Armon BLAIS had arrived from Delmas and we tried to put the fire out. However the fire extinguisher wouldn't work, and the small glass fire bombs we had were not much use. ENDS.

(P.T.O.)

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Thunderchild Indian Residential School

You will recall that the above Residential School was recently destroyed by fire. It is understood that Father Plourde, Superintendent of the Indian Welfare and Training Commission of the Oblate Order, and Reverend Father Boucher, Oblate Provincial for Alberta and Saskatchewan, recently visited the Minister and discussed with him the establishment of a temporary residential school in the buildings now at Delmas, Saskatchewan. These buildings were not destroyed when the main structure was burned.

We have now received a letter from the Reverend Father Plourde, reading as follows:

"It is our intention to continue to operate the above school and we have for this purpose the following buildings, all situated on the school ground or south boundary:

1) A brick house 30' x 30', two storeys and full basement. The attic, although not in use at the present time, can, with very little expense, be made into a dormitory. The building is hot air heated.

2) A frame house 20' x 24', two storeys and basement.

3) Garage 30' x 35', two storeys. This building will require a few windows and the walls must be winterized. This can be done with rough lumber and Ten Test.

4) Two very well built large granaries which may be used as sleeping quarters for some of the staff."
5) The house garage 20' x 20' can be converted into a laundry.

"To enable our Church authorities to carry on these plans, the following articles of furniture, bedding and laundry will be required:

1) 30 Complete beds including mattresses, pillows, blankets, sheets, pillow cases, towels.

2) 30 Desks, with class material.

3) Kitchen stove and utensils with refectory outfit.

4) Laundry equipment, which should include steam boiler, washing machine, dryer and wringer, and one small ironer.

5) Furthermore, the principal will need about 10,000' of building lumber and Ten Test, and ordinary building material such as nails, paper, etc.

"It is our purpose to provide at the present for 30 girls, and, if we find it possible later on, we shall add between 20 to 30 boys to the above number of children.

"I hope that you will be able to issue the necessary authority to proceed with the above plan."

We have been advised by Mr. Indian Agent Jones that we can obtain the beds, mattresses, blankets, pillows, folding tables and folding benches from the Provincial Government at Prince Albert. These supplies are available at War Assets Corporation prices. It is also understood that the other items are in fairly good supply. Therefore, authority is requested from the Minister for the following:

(a) the establishment of a temporary residential school with a pupilage of 30 to replace the former Thunderchild Residential School,

(b) the inclusion of $4,000.00 in the supplementary estimates to purchase the necessary supplies for the operation of this temporary school.

With reference to the above and to previous C.R.'s in this connection, this date, Oliver Longneck, 15 year old Indian boy of Sweetgrass I.R., and former student at the captionally noted school, now attending the Duck Lake Residential School for Indians was interviewed regarding his knowledge of the circumstances under which this fire occurred and the following statement was obtained:

BEGIN: "I, Oliver Longneck am 15 years of age. I have only been at this school in Duck Lake for a short time, previous to this I was attending the Indian Residential School in Delmas, Saskatchewan for approximately 8 years. I am now in grade 6. On the day of the fire (Jan.13) I attended the days classes which end at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. At this time I went to the barns to milk the cows which we finished around 5:00 o'clock and then done the regular chores in the barn finishing around 5:45 p.m. From here I went to supper which I finished around 6:30. After supper I went down to the basement with Ernest Bear to find my mitts which I had left in the basement. We looked around in the washing room and then Sister Gerard—de Rosaire came down into the basement and told us to go upstairs. A few minutes later Sister Yvonne—de—Sacre Coeur came down the stairs and I asked her if she had seen my mitts. She told us to go upstairs, which we did. I then went outside with Edwin Tootosis to play hockey where we stayed for about one half an hour. Ernest Bear stayed inside and as far as I know went to the recreation room. At about 7:15 in the evening I went to the recreation room to listen to the radio and about 15 minutes later Sister St. Jerome who was in charge of the recreation room told us that there was a fire in the basement and that we were to file outside.

I have permission from the principal to smoke in the pump house but not inside the school and I was not smoking with Ernest Bear in the basement.

(signed) Oliver Longneck

This boy emphatically denied having been smoking in the basement of the school on the night of the fire and further stated that there were no signs of any fire during the time that he and Ernest Bear were in the basement.

2. Oliver Longneck is an intelligent boy, speaks very good English and is extremely well mannered. It appears from his bearing and knowledge that he is one of the leaders of the children.

My dear Minister:

Following my interview with you in the House yesterday afternoon with reference to the reconstruction of the Indian School at Dalmas, Sask., which was destroyed by fire on the 13th of January last, I find that I have taken this matter up first with the Hon. Glen, as well as with the Rt. Hon. J.J. Gardiner, in February last.

My initial representations by letter with these ministers have been followed up by numerous interviews with them. As it is now four months that this matter has been considered by the Department, it is felt by the Principal of this school, Father J.B. Casana, that some final decision should be rendered in the matter. In order to expedite matters I must say that the plans for the schools already built at Latoon and Lebrets could be used, and there would then be no delay in the drawing up of architectural plans.

There is more than 200 Indian youths at the Dalmas School, and should this school now revert to a day school rather than a residential school, it will mean that the progress made will be practically abandoned, owing to the fact that the day school will not be attended by the Indian children due to the nomadic attitude of their parents.

Again, to further delay the construction of this school means that the training which has been given these children in the past years, will be nullified almost entirely if this good work is not continued.

The Principal of this school has an experience
of twenty-four years among Indians, is ready to continue his work if only the Department will authorize him to effectively do so.

Once again, it is felt that a day school rather than a residential school is an entire waste of money.

May I not ask your most sympathetic consideration of this case, and may I not hear from you with a final decision in the matter.

Very sincerely yours,

May I be allowed to bring to your attention once more the case of the above school for immediate consideration.

You will remember that the sum of $4,000.00 was allowed to provide for temporary arrangements and repairs to existing buildings so as to accommodate about thirty children. I am informed that close to two hundred children, of school age, will be without accommodation this fall, unless some other arrangements are made to provide better accommodation.

When the new school is put up, this building would be of use as a recreation centre for both school children and visiting Indians. If you approve of this plan, I would suggest that the principal, in order to expedite the undertaking, be allowed to do the purchasing from approved lists of dealers of all materials needed and also be permitted to engage a master-carpenter and other help, so as to press the construction as rapidly as possible.
I therefore hope that you will be good enough to give this plan your approval in the shortest time possible and notify Reverend Father Boucher, Provincial, of your decision by an air mail letter or a telegram. Re: Proposed rebuilding of Thunderchild Indian Residential School.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 20th instant, File 105-1-5 (E), in connection with the above.

There are many things to consider in connection with erecting a temporary building on the foundation of the old Thunderchild Residential School. It is true that it would be possible to rebuild a temporary building on the old foundation, but I have some doubt that it would be a wise course to follow, planning a suitable building to comply with the lay-out of the old foundation.

There has been some mention of an amount of $20,000.00 being sufficient to accommodate 60 children. I am sure that $20,000.00 will not be sufficient to provide all that is necessary in dormitories, kitchen, laundry, and classroom space and equipment for 60 children. We must also bear in mind that fire regulations in Saskatchewan for institutions where sleeping accommodation is provided have become very strict. How far we must go toward meeting provincial requirements is not for me to decide, but I must say that we have been subjected to considerable criticism in connection with some of our residential schools with regard to fire hazards. This fact must be kept in mind in planning even a temporary building for residential purposes.

There has been a strong move lately on the part of the Indian parents of the Battleford area to have day schools in preference to residential schools. This applies particularly to the Sweetgrass and Poundmaker Reserves, from which the majority of the pupils of the former Thunderchild School were recruited. This fact also must be borne in mind when making a decision as to the replacement of that school.

Of course there are some children in that area whose home conditions suggest that a residential school would serve better. There is also the question of transportation and the distance to travel to and from a day school. With this in mind it is my opinion that those parents who are determined to have the services of day schools should be reminded that they are expected to do everything possible on their part to promote regular attendance at a day school without expecting the Department to assume full responsibility for the transportation. On most reserves it is impossible to locate a day school in such a position that all children of school age can attend without difficulty during the winter. However, I believe that the parents of the children on both Poundmaker and Sweetgrass Reserves would be quite prepared to assume this responsibility if they were given day schools.

With the erection of the day school at the Meadow Lake Reserve, which has just been authorized to immediately commence, the number of children of school age without accommodation will, I believe, be somewhat less than 200, but...
less than 200, but certainly much in excess of 60, which it is proposed the temporary building will accommodate.

I am in favour of the erection of a small residential school to replace the former Thunderchild Residential School. I would suggest that it be made to accommodate about 75 pupils who, for some reason cannot regularly attend day schools, but I believe that it would be in the best interests of all concerned to plan on a well constructed residential school next year rather than to at once commence the erection of a temporary building to accommodate 60 pupils, as which would never be very satisfactory. The old foundation and excavation will save us little in the construction of a good school and I believe that the idea should be discarded. To plan the erection of a new building to comply with an old foundation is not considered economically sound, as the small amount saved would not justify the erection of a badly planned building. After giving the matter considerable thought I am doubtful that any money would be saved by using the old foundation.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,

Memorandum:

Proposed Rebuilding - Thunderchild Residential School.

You will recall our previous discussions with regard to the rebuilding of the Thunderchild Residential School at Delmas, Saskatchewan. Letters have been received from Mr. M. Boivin, M.P., and Mr. Paul Prince, M.L.A., Battleford, Sask., concerning the rebuilding of this school and on September 21 I submitted a brief summary on this situation to you.

We have now received a report from Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander, our Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan, concerning the proposal made to advance $20,000.00 to the Oblate Order for the reconstruction of this school. For your information I am attaching a copy of this report, wherein you will note that the Indians on the Sweetgrass, Poundmaker and Meadow Lake Reserves have been requesting the establishment of day schools on their reserves. Mr. Ostrander feels that these requests must be taken into consideration when we are deliberating the re-erection of this school.

Therefore, it is my intention to have the Survey Officer of the Education Division visit both the Sweetgrass and Poundmaker Reserves during the next fortnight, with a view to ascertaining the feasibility of operating day schools for the Indian children living there. Authority has already been granted for the erection of a day school on the Meadow Lake Reserve.

Acting Director.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Report re Replacement of Thunderchild Residential School.

Our officials question the suitability of Delmas, Saskatchewan, as the location for a new residential school with a pupilage of 150, as suggested by the local Missionary.

The pupilage at the burned school was 120. These children were mainly drawn from the following reserves:

Meadow Lake,
Moosomin,
Foundmaker,
Red Pheasant,
Sweetgrass.

It is felt that many of these children could be served by day schools. The present building costs of residential schools and the high per capita rate required to maintain children in them are such as to render the education of children in such institutions a very expensive undertaking.

Therefore we feel that residential schools should be built only where there is no possibility of educating the children with day schools and only with a pupilage adjusted to the requirements of the population to be served and of economical operation.

We are just now finishing the construction of a one-room day school and attached teacher's residence at Meadow Lake. A qualified and experienced male teacher has been hired.
and this school will open in the near future. This should provide adequate educational facilities for the children of this reserve who can walk to the school. We intend to erect similar buildings this year on the Poundmaker and Red Pheasant Reserves. Arrangements were made some months ago to have the children from the Moosomin Reserve attend a nearby provincial school. The residents of Sweetgrass Reserve have for years been requesting a day school and the site for a school on that reserve has been determined. If our plans are put into effect, there will therefore not be, in the area formerly served by the school at Delmas, enough children to warrant the building of a residential school for 150 pupils.

We have had some correspondence with our field officials concerning the pupilage of the proposed new residential school. The following extract from a letter from Mr. Ostrander, dated September 30, 1948, is pertinent:

"There has been a strong move lately on the part of the Indian parents of the Battleford area to have day schools in preference to residential schools. This applies particularly to the Sweetgrass and Poundmaker Reserves, from which the majority of the pupils of the former Thunderchild School were recruited. This fact also must be borne in mind when making a decision as to the replacement of that school.

"Of course there are some children in that area whose home conditions suggest that a residential school would serve better. There is also the question of transportation and the distance to travel to and from a day school. With this in mind it is my opinion that those parents who are determined to have the services of day schools should be reminded that they are expected to do everything possible on their part to promote regular attendance at a day school without expecting the Department to assume full responsibility for the transportation. On most reserves it is impossible to locate a day school in such a position that all children of school age can..."
attend without difficulty during the winter. However, I believe that the parents of the children on both Poundmaker and Sweetgrass Reserves would be quite prepared to assume this responsibility if they were given day schools.

"With the erection of the day school at the Meadow Lake Reserve, which has just been authorized to immediately commence, the number of children of school age without accommodation will, I believe, be somewhat less than 200, but certainly much in excess of 60, which it is proposed the temporary building will accommodate.

"I am in favour of the erection of a small residential school to replace the former Thunderchild Residential School. I would suggest that it be made to accommodate about 75 pupils who, for some reason, cannot regularly attend day schools, but I believe that it would be in the best interests of all concerned to plan on a well constructed residential school next year rather than to at once commence the erection of a temporary building to accommodate 60 pupils, and which would never be very satisfactory."

I concur in Mr. Ostrander's recommendation that a small residential school, with a pupilage of 75, be erected to replace the Thunderchild Residential School and that the remaining children attend the day schools erected or to be erected on their home reserves. A sum of $200,000.00 is included in our 1949-50 Estimates for the reconstruction of this school and if you concur, I will request that plans be prepared at once for a small residential school with a pupilage of 75. We are writing to Mr. Ostrander with regard to Superintendent Bell's recommendation that this proposed new school be located near Battleford, where electricity would be available, rather than at Delmas, which is quite isolated.

I would prefer to avoid any commitment to a new residential school if at all possible. If it is absolutely necessary to build such a school I would be prepared to agree to your recommendation. Please hold off the rush to decide again before deciding.

Director.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE MINISTER:

Proposed Indian Residential School at Delmas, Saskatchewan

A sum of $100,000 is included in the 1949-50 Estimates to commence construction of this school, the estimated cost of which is $200,000.

Although the old school, which was destroyed by fire in 1948, had a pupilage of 120, the construction of day schools on reserves in the area from which this pupilage was drawn removes the need of a residential school of such capacity. The new day school for the Meadow Lake Reserve is nearing completion and our 1949-50 programme calls for the construction of similar schools on the Poundmaker and Red Pheasant Reserves. Many of the pupils of the old residential school were recruited from these reserves.

These circumstances suggest that a residential school with accommodation for 75 pupils would meet our requirements. However, if it is so desired, plans for a school to accommodate 100 pupils will be prepared, with a view to keeping the cost within the amount provided in the Estimates. It would be possible to justify a school of this size but our educational advisers are not prepared to recommend a school for 120 pupils.

The Church authorities will be able to handle the school, financially, on the basis of 100 pupils.

(sgd) H.L. Keenleyside

MEMORANDUM FOR THE MINISTER:

Proposed Indian Residential School at Delmas, Saskatchewan

You will recall that Mr. W.A. Boucher, M.P., spoke to you about the proposal to reconstruct the Indian residential school at Delmas. This matter has been occupying the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch for some time and with your approval, it was decided to construct certain day schools in this general vicinity which would reduce the pressure on the accommodation required in any residential school that might be constructed. It is the opinion of the officers concerned that there will be no necessity for a residential school with accommodation for more than 75 pupils. The effort of the interested church to obtain a larger school is based on their hostility to the programme of substituting day schools for residential schools. This programme, however, has the support of all other educational authorities, is in accordance with the views of Parliamentary Committee, and has been adopted for some time as departmental policy.

With regard to the particular situation at Delmas, I think that all that it is necessary to say to Mr. Boucher is that all of the children of the vicinity, who will not be taken care of in day schools, will be provided for in the residential school which is to be constructed. Our present estimate of this number is that it will not exceed 75.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

Replacement of Thunderchild Indian Residential School

It has been decided to erect a new Thunderchild Residential School from a pupilage of 120. In view of your specific recommendations of September 30, 1948, I feel that you should be advised directly by me as to the reasons why your recommendations have not been followed in full.

As you are no doubt aware, considerable pressure was brought to bear upon the Department for the purchase of the Lebret Scholasticate. This was coupled with the re-erection of the Thunderchild Residential School with a pupilage of 120 and not 75 as recommended by departmental officials.

These representations have taken place over the last two months and finally culminated in a meeting with the Prime Minister. As a result of this meeting, the following decisions were reached:

(1) No further effort would be made to sell the Lebret Scholasticate to the Department.

(2) That the above residential school would be built with a pupilage of 120.

This represents a compromise which, I feel is to our benefit, although possibly not all that we would have recommended.

I understand that you have also discussed with the Superintendent of Education, the possibility of having this school erected near Battleford rather than at Delmas again. We have just received a letter from Father Cabana indicating that the Canadian National Railways will no longer be using Delmas as a water stop, and will abolish their water tank there. The Oblate Provincial has advised that a site near Battleford would be preferable for the future operation of this school.

I understand that Mr. Indian Superintendent Bell is also aware of one site that might be suitable. This is the farm owned by Mr. Spears. You, of course, will wish to visit the area and may possibly find a more suitable location. We feel that aside from good farm land, we must be assured of an adequate water supply and a source of electricity. We do not want to have a generating plant at the school and, therefore, Hydro is most essential.

I hope that the above letter will clarify this situation in your mind and provide factual knowledge to dispel the many rumours which have doubtless reached you.

With kindest personal regards,

Director.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to the matter of the proposed re-establishment of the Thunderchild Indian Residential School at the Battleford Agency, and your letter of the 28th ultimo, File 663-5 (E) on the subject, I am enclosing herewith a rough plan of the arrangement of the buildings on the "Speers" farm, near the Town of Battleford. This farm contains 900 acres of land under cultivation and is on the Battle River, approximately 2 miles north-west of the Town of Battleford. There is an excellent well on the farm 4' in diameter and 25' deep, with cast-iron cribbing, fed by a spring. This well has supplied water in the past for 100 head of cattle and all household requirements, and is excellent water. Of course the Battle River, which runs through the farm, could be put to use if it was found that the supply of water in the well was not sufficient. However, I do not think that this would ever be necessary.

The power line of the Saskatchewan Power Commission supplies electricity.

Number of acres under cultivation - 900 acres, of which approximately 125 acres can be irrigated.

The fences are in good repair, and the land is all fenced.

About 50% of the fencing is with page wire. The other 50% is with two strand barbed wire.

Enclosed with the rough plan of the distribution of the buildings is an aerial photograph showing most of the farm, the buildings, and the Battle River, also #5 Highway, which is the main highway between Winnipeg and Edmonton.

I believe that the land in question is situated perfectly for the site of an Indian residential school. However, I believe that the suggested price is too high, and perhaps might be reduced somewhat if an official of the Department is given authority to actually commence negotiations. The price quoted is $50.00 per acre for 160 acres of land which can be irrigated, or $8,000.00; $35.00 per acre for 740 acres which can be irrigated, totalling $25,900.00, or a total price of $33,900.00. I sometimes think that negotiations for a purchase of this kind can be carried out better through an independent person who is not known to be negotiating on behalf of the Government, as there seems to be a natural tendency to lay it on a little heavier if the Government is paying. If it reaches that point may I make the suggestion that this course be followed.

The buildings are not all in a good state of repair, by any means. The barn, root house, garage, and hen house, with some repairs, could be made very useful for an Indian residential school. The other buildings are of little value to us, but all could be temporarily used until funds were available to replace them with more suitable buildings. The barn has been kept in normally good repair.
good repair, as the farm has been operated as a dairy, and the barn was regularly inspected as to sanitation, etc. It will be noted that there is a fairly large house, 29' x 42', with a lean-to 12½' x 42', and a smaller house which would serve as a residence for some other member of the school staff. Dear Mr. MacKay:

Reverend Father A. Boucher, O.M.I., Provincial of the Edmonton Province, under whose jurisdiction the school at Delmas is operated, and myself have had occasion to see Mr. B.F. Neary, Superintendent of Indian Education, re the site of the new Delmas Indian Residential School.

This change was made necessary because the pipeline had to be renewed and the C.N.R. found it more economical to change the site of its water supply.

However this water line from the Delmas Station to the River is now available if you should decide to build the new School on the old site. Of course it is likely that the old pipeline will have to be replaced, but we believe that this can be renewed cheaply enough. Moreover we are informed that there is quite a large halfbreed group in the suburbs of Battleford which would be detrimental to the proper training of our Indian pupils, particularly our young girls.

These reasons incline all of us to the opinion that, if it is at all possible, the old site should be kept.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR OF LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

Proposed Thunderchild Residential School

This residential school, which burned down last year, was situated at Delmas Saskatchewan. This site was unsatisfactory because it lacked two essential services, namely, electricity and adequate supply of water.

During the past year, the first difficulty has been eliminated by the fact that the Saskatchewan Branch Hydro system has extended its line through the village of Delmas.

The second difficulty, that of the water, still remains, but a proposed solution has recently been presented. Formerly, the school was operated with water from the C.N.R. tank at its station in Delmas. The railway obtained its water from the nearby Battle River and carried it by a water pipe to the tank. This pipe line now has to be renewed, and the C.N.R. has decided to change the site of its water supply to another station ten or fifteen miles distant.

It is the contention of the Oblate Fathers that the old pipe line can be replaced cheaply and that an adequate supply of water for this school could be obtained. They have also asked that we investigate the possibility of obtaining water from a spring which is a short distance from the school. They have forwarded a rough sketch of the school grounds and the old water system. I have attached this sketch to my memorandum.
We have had some considerable correspondence already concerning the relocation of this school. Originally, the proposal was made to have it situated near Battleford, Saskatchewan. However, if a satisfactory water supply can be obtained for a reasonable sum at Delmas, it would seem to be feasible to re-erect the school at Delmas.

It would be appreciated, therefore, if one of your engineers could be sent to Delmas, Saskatchewan, in the near future to carry out a thorough survey of the local water supply possibility and to report on the estimated cost of providing an adequate system for this proposed residential school of some 120 pupils and 20 staff members.

Director.
Ottawa, June 1, 1949.

Dear Sir:

Acting according to your instructions in regard to
the Thunderchild Indian Residential School, both Mr. W.J.
Kerr and myself proceeded to Delmas and made a survey and
inspection of the school site. The following is the
result of our investigation:

The school is situated on the S.E. ¼ Sec. 6, Tp. 46,
Rge 18, West of the 3rd M., adjoining the Hamlet of Delmas
on the North, approximately 20 miles West of the Town of
Battleford on the C.N.R., laying between the North Saskatchewan
River 1 mile North and the Battle River six miles South.

The school was burned to the ground nearly two years
ago, and all that remains at present are the farm buildings
and rectory. The population of the school was 125 children,
16 nuns, and 6 of a staff. The school served children
from the following Reservations: Sweetgrass - 16 miles south,
Poundmaker - 25 miles southwest, Redpheasant - 40 miles
West, Moosomin - 25 miles north, Meadow Lake - 125 miles
north, and Thunderchild - 50 miles northwest.

The school farm comprises 210 acres, out of these 40
acres are taken up in buildings, playgrounds etc. leaving
170 acres for cultivation and pasture. Arrangements are
being made to purchase the half section adjoining to the
west and north to the river.

During the period the school was operated, the farm
accommodated the following head of stock:

- 15 milk cows
- 25 beef cattle
- 50 pigs
- 4 horses

Water Supply: From 1905 to 1935 water was obtained
from wells supplemented by hauling from the North Saskatchewan
River. This was superseded by obtaining water from the pipe
line operated by the C.N.R. which passed close by the school
property. This line is of 6 inch diameter, and was connected
to the school with 1½" W.I. pipe.

The 6" line was installed in the year 1907 together
with 25 H.P. Fairbanks Morse gasoline engine, and pump. The
whole layout is now obsolete and will have to be renewed before
water can be obtained from the river. The line is badly corroded
and leaks in several places. The railway has abandoned this
set-up for a supply about 20 miles west.
From the river to where the school supply line takes off, the difference in elevation is 255 feet and about 7,000 feet in length.

Considering the obsolete character of this water supply, and age of engine and pump, it is deemed advisable not to purchase as it would cost more to put it in operation than by constructing a new line with electric motor and pump.

A Saskatchewan Power Commission Transmission line which serves the Hamlet of Delmas runs from the river south past the school site. A short lead from this line at the river to the pump house could be installed very reasonably together with transformer and motor and pump.

The supply from wells in the vicinity of the school is limited to approximately one hundred and twenty five gallons per hour, which is about twenty percent of the amount needed when the laundry is in operation. The school when in operation will consume around ten thousand gallons per day. The well which is located immediately north of the school site was investigated. A cribbing 6' x 5' has been set which is 5' deep and water coming within 1.7' of the surface (3.3' deep); according to our test this well would not produce over 100 gallons per hour. This water was analyzed sometime ago and the result was unfit for human consumption, as the supply was contaminated. This was possibly due to drainage from the Hamlet of Delmas which is located about 1,500 feet distant. We were unable to locate the old analysis and another sample of this water is being tested at the present time. The result of same will be forwarded when completed.

Another well was tested about 1,000 feet south east of the school on private property. The cribbing in this well is 2'6" x 2'9" and the well is 25 feet in depth. It has been in use for 30 years and has always maintained a depth of 2 feet. Our test indicated a rate of flow of 125-150 gallons per hour although local residents claim that from 10-12 barrels an hour have been taken out. Most wells in the community have sandy bottoms, but above mentioned well is located in a gravel bed about two feet in depth. A water sample was taken of this well also, and the result will be forwarded when received from the laboratory. Considering the small amount of water which can be obtained from the above wells, it is recommended that water be taken from the river where an assured supply can be looked for at all times.

The cost of this line from the river to the school site is as follows:

| Item                                      | Cost     |
|-------------------------------------------|----------|
| Clearing and Grubbing 1 acre               | $250.00  |
| Excavation & Backfilling 2'x8'x            |          |
| 7000'                                     | 4,150.00 |
| Laying pipe 7000' @ .20                    | 1,400.00 |
| Cost of pipe 7000' @ 1.00 per ft.          | 7,000.00 |
| Motor & Pump 85% efficiency                | 1,500.00 |
| (14000 gallons per day)                   |          |
| Transformer & Installation                | 1,000.00 |
| Cost of well                              | 1,200.00 |
| Pump House                                | 800.00   |
| Contingencies 10%                          | 1,730.00 |
|                                           | 18,030.00|

This is based on using 4" wood stave pipe, treated and wire wrapped; if iron or galvanized pipe is used add $5,600.00 in addition to the above.
The river carries a great amount of silt, and it may be necessary to install a silting basin so as to keep the pipe line clear and assure the school clear water. During the inspection it was learned that the Railway had a most difficult time to keep their pipe line clear during the spring and summer seasons.

Sewage Disposal: The ground immediately north of the proposed school drops at the rate of 2 feet in the hundred, and conditions for sewage disposal are ideal, as absorption is above medium; would recommend a No. 8 Septic tank, with 1,400 lineal feet of 4" drains. The outfall would be in the farm land approximately 350 feet north of the school building. The soil is sandy and absorption fairly rapid.

Electric Power: The power lines of the Saskatchewan Power Commission is located on the east side of the north and south road allowance, 400 feet from the school. As a matter of fact some of the remaining buildings are connected at the present time.

Yours truly,

F.J. Clark,
Engineering and Construction Division.
MEMORANDUM

OTTAWA, September 20, 1949.

Re: Proposed Thunderchild Indian Residential School.

Referring to the request of the Director of Indian Affairs under date of June 1st, 1949, for a report on the Water Supply available for the proposed Thunderchild Residential School, attached in duplicate is a report by Mr. Clark accompanied by one white printed copy of each of two plans showing the proposed site for the school, and a key plan of the surrounding area.

You will observe that Mr. Clark recommends water for the school be obtained as in the past, from the North Saskatchewan River.

In a covering letter Mr. Perrie states as follows:

"You will note that, in the event of a new school being erected upon the property owned at Delmas, power may be easily obtained from the Saskatchewan Power Commission and the matter of sewage disposal presents no difficulties. Water can not be obtained in ample quantities from either of the wells referred to by the Oblate Fathers as a possible source of supply. An ample supply of water can however be obtained from the same source as formerly, namely the North Saskatchewan River.

Mr. Clark's estimate of the cost of installing a pumping station at the river and piping water to the school site is, I believe, approximately correct, but as stated in his report some difficulties may be encountered because of silting in the river bed. These difficulties are met with at practically all points along the Saskatchewan River and must be contended with if water is to be obtained from that source. The amount of $1,730.00, which is estimated by Mr. Clark for contingencies, might not prove sufficient to overcome this difficulty and I would recommend that an additional $2,000.00 be estimated for this purpose, thereby increasing his estimate to $21,030.00.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
The Director of Indian Affairs, in his memorandum of June 1, 1949, mentions that some consideration has been given to the relocation of this school in the vicinity of Battleford, Sask. This proposal would, if the school were erected in the immediate vicinity of Battleford, make it possible to reduce materially the cost of the school water supply but it is doubtful that any saving might be effected in the cost of electrical power or sewage disposal. The selection of such a site would, however, have certain disadvantages which cannot be ignored. The most important matters to be considered in this regard are:

(1) The necessity of replacing the many buildings that are now in use at the present site.

(2) The fact that the land generally, in the immediate vicinity of Battleford, is not considered as suitable for farming as that in the vicinity of Delmas.

In view of the above it is recommended that the proposed new school be erected upon the old school site.

It would appear that no difficulty is likely to arise in regard to the supply of electrical power or to sewage disposal. If, however, any troubles were previously experienced with the sewage disposal at this school, we should like to be informed so that any necessary remedial steps could be taken if it should be decided to proceed with the construction of a new school on the old site.

With regard to the estimated cost of the proposed water system we believe that the following items should be added to the cost of $19,030.00 as estimated by Mr. Clark:

- Hypochlorinator: $500.00
- Filtration gallery at intake etc.: $2000.00
- Additional cost of pipe line to school: $2000.00
- Concrete tank at school (10,000 gals): $1500.00

Total: $6000.00

The estimate for the water system will thus total $25,000.00, and unless it is considered desirable to separate the school from the farm, it is recommended that the school be rebuilt on the old site at Delmas.

R.A. Campbell,
for Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

Sir:-

I beg to forward herewith copy of a letter received from Rev. J.H.O. Allard, C.M.I., Principal of the Thunderchild Residential School, re Chas Mirasty, pay ticket #62 of Meadow Lake Band and pupil #113 of the above noted school, which is self explanatory.

This boy approached me on the reserve this summer while he was on his vacation and seems very anxious to learn a trade.

He is a good boy, very bright and willing and comes from a good family, both his parents being good Indians and bright and intelligent. I would strongly recommend that if anything can be done for this boy, it should be, as he is certainly worthy of any assistance that can be given.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

S.L. Macdonald,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 3rd, 1936.

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Thunderchild Indian Residential School with reference to Charles Mirasty - No. 113.

Reverend Father Allard should communicate with the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School and, if the latter considers that Mirasty could be given a trade at the Qu'Appelle School, the Department will approve of his transfer. In the event of his being transferred, you should so advise us, stating the date on which he left the Thunderchild School.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

The Nuttunee-Indian-Sick-

Edwin Nuttunee, an educated Indian living at Red Thosant, P.O. Sask., a member of the Red Thosant Band of the Cree Nation wishes that his daughter Ellinor Jean age 16 years, be given immediate hospital care in order to save her from death from consumption. The following are the facts:

1. When she was 9 years old she was relinquished by her said father into the care of the St. Barnabas School at Onion Lake, Sask., and she has remained in the care of said school until last May.

2. Last May the principal of the school brought the child back to parents a month before the school closed, telling them that the child had had a slight hemorrhage. This condition had been apparent for about a year and that the child had been receiving ultra violet ray treatment during the winter.

3. The Father then made arrangements and had the child examined by the Tubercular Clinic the 1st Thursday in June here; the doctors recommended hospital care. Dr. MacQuay and Dr. Dunn both of Battleford, Sask., are familiar with the condition of the child.

4. About Aug. 4/37, I wrote to Dr. Stone in your care, complaining that while hospital care was recommended nothing was being done and asking for hospital care for the child. This letter I showed to Mr. Macdonald, Indian Agent at Battleford, and he said "that is right, I will write and attach your letter to one I will write." I have had no word since and no action.

7.
The Father is very anxious about his child. He may lose her if care is not taken. The child was well when she went to the school and contracted the disease there. It is suggested that the child should not be now thrown back on the hands of the parents who have no knowledge nor money to care for her condition. In addition to that, they have other children, one little fellow, who may contract the disease from their sister. They do not know whether or not the sister can infect them, nor what to do nor how to do it. They know that there is care for sick white children and believe the same care should be afforded to Indian children. The little girl also plays around with other children on the reserve and she may be a focal point for infection of many of them. Mr. Armstrong came to see me today and told me that he had taken his children from this School, because they were not making satisfactory progress with their studies, and because they were not being treated kindly.

This indicated to the Father the kind of treatment the Children would receive in his absence, and this coupled with the fact that they are making practically no progress in their work, determined him to take them away and have them educated in a day school close by, and have them live at home.

REPORT OF SISTER SUPERIOR CONCERNING ARMSTRONG CHILDREN.

It was on Sunday, September 19th, at 2 o'clock that Phillip Armstrong took his two boys, Jimmy and Peter, to school. On his arrival here, he asked to see the Superior. He was accompanied by a gentleman, Mr. Wuttunee, I believe, and a lady.

He told me then, that he had written to the Department, asking authorization to take his children away from this school and place them at the day school at Red Pheasant.

When I entered the parlor to interview Mr. Armstrong, I was accompanied by two other members of the staff: Sisters Sainte-Theresia and Sainte-Marie de Jérusalem. The older boy had already gone out of the house being unwilling to remain. I asked Mr. Armstrong if it was his will that the children would stay at school, and he answered in the affirmative until the answer from the Department would arrive, said he, stating that however the children themselves were reluctant.

I then requested one of the older girls who was near by to go out and call Jimmy, without telling him why he was wanted. The boy came promptly at the call and sat by his father with his younger brother by his side. Not knowing if Mr. Armstrong was familiar enough with the English language to understand, I asked the gentleman who was with him to interpret to him that he need not worry about his children as they would be well looked after here. We then spoke to the two children who broke into tears. Turning to Mr. Armstrong, I gave him to understand that if he himself would leave immediately (sometimes the Indians stay in the neighborhood a few days when they take their children back to school, and this makes it all the harder for those more inclined to be homesick) the children would soon be consoled, at the same time I promised candy to the young one, chocolate to the older one.

Mr. Armstrong asked me to see that they would not escape and follow him when he left the house. I tried to persuade them to come with me where I keep a candy store; the younger boy only followed Sister Sainte-Theresia to the candy store, the older one remained by his father. It seems to me that this would emphasise that Mr. Armstrong's statement was erroneous when he reported that BOTH children had been slapped across the face. The young one not being there, how can he report on him? As Mr. Armstrong arose to go, the boy bounded after him. We tried to hold him back and he struggled fiercely to free himself. I held him by the wrists, the other Sister, by the arms. The boy was yelling so savagely that I put his own hand before his mouth. This scene lasted for a space of possibly one minute. Mr. Armstrong had made but a few steps towards the door, he was not yet out of the room, but hearing the boy scream in like manner, he took the boy away saying: come to the house, or some such sentence. He called for the other one who had gone with Sister for candy, without saying more, he took both children away. Not another word was said by us neither, and we have never heard from him since.

His daughter had arrived at school here three weeks previous to this event and, had she been willing to go, he would have taken her away too, for he had told her of his intentions; but seeing she was desirous of remaining here, he seemed to leave the matter for her to decide. Besides, the child stated that her father was greatly displeased with her because she manifested the desire to stay here.

Delmas, Sask.
October 27, 1937.

Report of the Principal concerning Philip Armstrong

On the 19th day of September, which was a Sunday, about half past twelve, I heard that the boys of Philip Armstrong, Indian of Red-Pheasant, were come back to school. In fact, in leaving the school, I saw the two boys, Jimmy and Peter, who seemed to be of good humour. After shaking hands with them, I returned to the priest-house and there I met Philip Armstrong with another Indian. We had a talk on the schools, but Philip passed no special remark on our school; he seemed to be pleased to bring back his two boys to school. Finally, he asked me to give all the family their meal at noon and 2 gallons of gas and one quart of oil for the car. I gave him a note for the Sisters in order that all the family be fed at school gratis and I notified the farmer to give him gas and oil. So, afterwards, they went to school and I did not see them after.

What happened at school has been related by Sister Superior. I was not present. I must say however that Philip Armstrong has been well treated at school, and what I heard from him when talking with me could not suppose that he would be so foolish.

It is only about 6 o'clock in the evening that I knew Philip Armstrong had taken back his boys to home.

Re: Children of Philip Armstrong

Dear Sir:

May I refer to your letter of September 20, 1937, and departmental reply thereto dated October 21, 1937.

I may state that the Department is in receipt of a report from Indian Agent S. L. Macdonald, Battleford, Sask., in which he deals in detail with the complaint referred to by Philip Armstrong when he visited your office a few weeks ago.

It would appear from this report that Philip Armstrong, accompanied by his two children - Jimmie and Peter - called at the Thunderchild Indian Residential School on Sunday, September 19th, apparently with the object of having his children enrolled at the school for the academic year 1937-38. Mr. Armstrong first interviewed the Principal but did not intimate in his interview that the children were in any sense dissatisfied with the school. The Principal made arrangements to have the father and those accompanying him provided with a meal and also made arrangements whereby Mr. Armstrong was provided with two gallons of gasoline and a gallon of oil from the supply kept at the institution. Mr. Armstrong later interviewed the Sister Superior and told her that he had written to the Department, asking for the necessary authorization to take his children away from the residential school and place them at the day school at Red Pheasant. He stated, however, that he was willing to have his

F. R. Conroy, Esq., LL.B.,
Barrister,
North Battleford, Sask.
have his children enrolled at the Thunderchild School until a decision had been reached by the Department. It would appear that, during the course of this interview, the younger boy left with Sister St. Theresia to obtain candy at the candy store, the older boy remaining with his father. When the time arrived for Mr. Armstrong to leave the school, the boy appeared anxious to leave with him. The Sister Superior, in an attempt to prevent this, held the boy by the wrists and for a moment or two put his own hand over his mouth in an attempt to keep him from yelling so vigorously. When the father heard the noise he returned, took the boy with him and later called for the younger boy at the candy store and, with them, left the school. The father made no comment upon what had taken place and a daughter already enrolled at the school remained in attendance. I was particularly interested to know that the Sister had to use an interpreter in her talk with Armstrong, despite the fact that the Agent informs me this man is an ex-pupil of the school, speaks English fluently and served four years overseas. This fact in itself may partially explain the reluctance or unwillingness of his boys to read successfully from the boys' story book during their visit to your office.

I have made a careful study of the Inspector's reports on the work of this school and find these uniformly satisfactory. I have also made a careful check of the reports in an attempt to discover if any complaints reached the Department with respect to the administration of the Thunderchild school. No complaints from parents, pupils or from the inspectors have reached the Department at any time over a long period of years. I am enclosing herewith, for your information, an excerpt from a report on this school dated February 22, 1937, submitted by Mr. Campbell Innes, Inspector of Public Schools, Province of Saskatchewan.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the THUNDERCHILD RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL. December 11, 1924.

I feel that the Department at Ottawa should supply at least two more sewing machines and also six more cows. It would then be possible to maintain a herd sufficient to supply the milk demand and also a certain amount of meat. Milk diet is acknowledged by all to be the most essential. The lesson has not been as well learned in Canada as it might have been but special instruction in this line is now in vogue. Here is a good place to make a start.

A new stable has recently been built. At present there are six cows but these are not sufficient to provide milk in proper quantities to eighty children and supply the demands for cooking.

Already 88 children on the roll.

W. M. Veazey, Insp.
Dear Sir,

Upon my asking to be authorized to increase the pupilage in our school from 90 to 120, your answer (Jan. 15 1925--File No. I05-I-I), as well as the answer of Mr. R. Ferrier, was that the question will be taken under consideration when we farm the land we have at Delmas, agricultural training is given to the children and ten cows are supplied at the school.

I feel certain that the Indian Department is as solicitous as I am myself, of enabling as many children as possible to partake in the advantages of instruction and education, and still it seems that its policy is depriving quite a few children of such advantages, and that because we are not, as you may see by our financial report, in a position of complying with your wishes, of fulfilling your conditions on secondary lines. May I hope that the Department will help me? Under Inspector Murrison's suggestion twice I have asked money to be granted to us for the acquisition of six milch cows. Let me note that $2000.00 were voted by the Government in March 1924 in favor of this our school, and so far have not been entirely spent. So you cannot be surprised that I am begging The Department that part of the balance left over from these $2000.00 be applied for the purchase of cows, so that one of the conditions imposed on us for increased pupilage will be met with.

Confident that my demand will receive favorable consideration, and be granted, I am

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant #105-1-4, with reference to the increased pupilage requested for the Thunderchild Indian Residential School, provided the management undertakes agricultural training and supplies a suitable number of milk cows.

I notice that the Principal is now asking the Department for assistance in the purchase of stock. There is no record in this office that he has referred the matter to Inspector Murison. If he did this by letter a record would be on our files, but he may have explained about this verbally when the Inspector was at the school.

In connection with this matter I would point out that some time ago when the matter of buying cows for Old Sun's School and for the Crowfoot School was under consideration, you informed me on April 10th, 1924, letter #104-1-14, that the Department would not supply them. In the face of this it is pretty hard for me to recommend that the Thunderchild School should get cows. I am still of the opinion that, as a general rule, the schools should finance this matter themselves, but in cases where this is impossible it might be money well spent for the Department to assist them, as it is very desirable and necessary to have a sufficient supply of milk at our Boarding schools.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott.

The church authorities have on several occasions requested the Department to increase the pupilage at the Thunderchild Indian Residential School. Favourable consideration was promised if this institution would provide agricultural training. Mr. Commissioner Graham will report when such training is being given.

When I learned the actual number of pupils that were at this school, I urged the management to supply more milch cows. As they have been under heavy capital expense lately in connection with an addition, they have approached the Department with a view to getting some help in this connection. I asked Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham for a recommendation concerning the supplying of six milch cows and he has replied in part as follows:

"Some time ago, when the matter of cows for Old Sun's School and for the Crowfoot School was under consideration, you informed me that the Department would not supply them. In the face of this, it is pretty hard for me to recommend that the Thunderchild School should get cows. I am still of the opinion that, as a general rule, the schools should finance this matter themselves, but in cases where this is impossible, it might be money well spent for the Department to assist them, as it is very desirable and necessary to have a sufficient supply of milk at our boarding schools."

As we have done very little for this institution, I wish to recommend that six milch cows be purchased for them. I believe that we should send the authority to Mr. Indian Agent Macdonald, who would cooperate with the principal in the matter of the purchase. I consider that $450 should be allowed for the six animals.

Russell T. Ferrie,
Supt. of Indian Education.

YUICHERHILD'S RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

May 11, 1929.

Dear Father Boys:

It has been drawn to my attention that practically no farming operations are carried on at the Thunderchild Indian Residential School. The graduates of this institution return to reserves where farming is the chief means of livelihood, and I am surprised to learn that the older boys are not being better equipped for their future. A few years ago, the Department had some correspondence with Rev. Father Guy in this connection. A barn was erected and a few milk cows purchased. Further, Mr. Commissioner Graham was authorized to provide the school with one or two teams of horses and some agricultural implements if farming was undertaken in earnest and a suitable instructor engaged.

I should be grateful if you will make arrangements to commence instruction in farming at this school this spring. You should instruct the Reverend Principal to write to the Department when it is timely to supply the horses and implements.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Since I have resumed the duties as Principal of the Thunderchild Residential School, my first attention was given to the correspondence between the Department and Rev. Father Angin.

A communication wanted that preparations and accommodations for beginning farm work should be effectuated without any further delay. Being well aware that farming is an essential part of an Indian boy's education, my views are, in this respect, fully in accordance with yours.

However, I find that for the present year, the estimate given by Rev. Father Angin re agricultural implements and work-horses, is somewhat over-rated. A suitable farm is undoubtedly of the most urgent need. As to the implements I would be satisfied with:

I Sulky combination plow.............16 in.
I Disc harrow..................14 to 16 ft.
I Seed drill........................20 discs.
I Teeth harrow....................5 sections.
I Binder
6 Brush hooks.
6 Axes..............................3 lbs.

As to the rest, I would prefer to have cancelled.

The Rev. Sisters have 50 acres ready for cultivation. Thirty more acres seem all what we can put under culture this coming spring as only four large boys are capable for the work. Besides, we have in all some 180 acres at our disposal on which we must reserve pasture land for our 16 head of cattle.

Taking this into consideration, it seems evident that we need not have other implements than those stated above, neither the work horses, as we can most conveniently make arrangements with our farm supervisor for the use of his horses.
Should you approve of such arrangements to begin with, in the course of the present year we would submit to you a more accurate estimate of other implements etc.

May we trust, that the Department will, as it always did in the past, use of its liberalties, on our behalf, and meet the rental payments to the Oblate Fathers.

Hoping that you will take the matter into consideration, and favor our request, I thank you in advance.

Yours very sincerely,

Principal.

Sir:

I beg to respectfully draw your attention to the renewal of the following requests which, in previous correspondence have been brought before the Department.

1. We would wish to put under cultivation this year a larger tract of land but we have none at our disposal. However, a party offers us the loan of a Half-Section, and this would be about what we would require.

2. Last year we cancelled the order for horses as we believed we could easily have the use of those of the farm supervisor, but, after trial, experience has taught us that too much money had already been expended for this, and now, we feel that it would be much more satisfactory if we owned the horses. We would therefore express the wish that these be supplied by the Department. Bartles here in Delmas, have for sale teams that could easily handled by our boys and they have asked to be favored.

3. The yearly rent of $100.00 for loan of land from the Oblate Fathers has been paid, and we trust that the Department will kindly refund same as well as take upon themselves to meet this yearly payment.

4. When Inspector Hamilton inspected our School last fall our urgent need of a hen-house was called to his notice and he promised to use his influence in our behalf. We have, as yet had no result of the decision that may have been taken in this connection.

5. We would also need beside the team of horses, a wagon, bob-sleigh, and set of harnesses.

With the confidence that the renewal of these requests will be favored with your consideration and approbation,

I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

Even Distribution Over the Entire Field

In addition to its labor-saving advantages the mechanical spreader does a more even job of spreading the manure. The Massey-Harris No. 8 can be set to spread 6 - 8 - 12 - 16 or 20 loads to the acre. This gives a wide range and the field is blanketed with a light, medium or heavy layer, as is desired.

The wide-spread distributor serves two purposes. First, it provides an extra beater to further pulverize the manure and, second, it distributes it in a wide, uniform strip, 7 feet wide, behind the rear wheels. In action the blades whirl rapidly cutting and beating the manure as it leaves the beaters, finally spreading it in a well-pulverized carpet.

Powerful, Effective Drive

A heavy chain and sprocket with large teeth transmits power to the main beater. An improved type positive action lifter disengages the chain from the sprocket when the machine is thrown out of gear. This type of drive is very reliable and is built to give long service.

Steel Apron with Star Ratchet Feed

The apron is made of angle steel slats and steel link chains—it is strong and durable. The movement of the apron is controlled by a star type ratchet feed which gives a wide range of feeds and which is very positive in operation. Shields protect the drive and ratchet feed also distributor chain from manure and other foreign substances.

Convenient Controls

The levers on the Massey-Harris No. 8 Spreader are easy to operate and are within handy reach of the operator.

Concave Cylinder Type

Those who prefer the concave cylinder type of root cutter and pulper will find in the Massey-Harris No. 1 a light running, compact machine that will give every satisfaction. It is strong and substantial and all wood parts are made from thoroughly air-seasoned stock.

The Massey-Harris No. 1 may be turned by hand or driven by power from either the right or left side as desired. Roller bearings in cages are used in the axle boxes to minimize friction.

One edge of the knives is sharpened for slicing; the other edge is for pulping. Slotted adjustment is provided for wear. Scrapers are arranged at each side to keep the pulp from lodging in the cylinder. The concave cylinder pulper takes up very little floor space.

Light draft is a feature of the Massey-Harris No. 8 Spreader. Both beaters are mounted on self-aligning bearings, assuring easy and smooth operation. Theft of Chickens from Rev. Joseph ANGIN -
Thunderchild Indian School, Delmas, Sask.

3-8-44

1. With reference to the above the following communication was received from the Rev. Joseph ANGIN, Principal of Thunderchild Indian School, Delmas, Sask.

August 1st, 1944.

Dear Sir:

I beg to let you know that in the period of July 5-15th about 20 hens have disappeared from the chicken coop and from July 19-26th 2 piglets. I suspect Mr. Laval Ayotte, one of my workers who has been engaged at school last April. Could you come to school and make an investigation in order to find the guilty one.

Yours truly,

sgd. Rev. Joseph Angin.
Principal.

2. This date the writer patrolled per P.C. 8116 to Delmas where investigation was made into this matter. The Rev. Joseph Angin interviewed stated that he had made two trips to Edmonton during which he was away from the Indian school from July 5-15th, and July 19-26th, and is of the opinion that the above noted hens and piglets were stolen while he was away. The chicken coop and pig pens are located approx. 30 yards west of the main building of the Indian school where the Sisters and students reside. Rev. Angin stated that the chickens are permitted to run free during the day but are kept in the chicken coop at night, the pigs remain in the open pen day and night. When interviewed concerning his suspicion of Laval Ayotte Rev. Angin stated that nothing had ever been stolen from the school before Ayotte was hired last April and further that Ayotte had attempted to buy two of the small pigs from him but upon learning the price of same had stated that he could not afford to buy them. Rev. Angin stated that though there was thirty hens missing he could not be sure how many of these were stolen as dogs in the district had killed quite a number of hens during the past three months. The hens are the Rhode Island Red specie and the pigs are the white Yorkshire breed.

3. Laval Ayotte was interviewed in this regard and volunteered the following statement.

"I am 42 years of age and have resided with my wife and family in Delmas since April last. I have worked at the..."
resides it would seem to be very difficult for anyone to steal and transport the hens and pigs from the grounds without attracting the attention of some of the persons residing at the school. All residents of the school were questioned in this regard however, but no one had noticed any unusual disturbances or any suspicious person around the chicken coop or passing through the grounds at any time.

7. Further enquiries are being made in this regard and contacts throughout the district and Delmas have been asked to keep a sharp lookout for these hens and pigs and to report any information received to this office, it is therefore respectfully requested that Diary Date be set as indicated hereunder when a further report will be submitted.

CARRIED FORWARD: D.D. 15-9-44.

EXPENSES PER F.93 Aug. 1-15th.

Const.
A.L. Bothamley, Reg.No.1821.
North Battleford Detachment.

O.C. "F" Division,
RCMP, REGINA, Sask.

Forwarded 9-8-44:
I am informed by Cst. Bothamley that the hogs are from four litters born this spring, a few weeks apart. They are of various sizes. When counted early in July there were thirty hogs of all ages, and sizes. There are now only twenty-eight and there is no information as to how the two became lost.

Early in July Rev. Father Angin counted two hundred hens. He knows that several were killed by dogs as the birds range at large during the daytime.

It would appear possible that two pigs and all of the missing hens could be accounted for by natural loss and this phase of the investigation is not being overlooked in the further enquiries that are being carried out.
