Theft of Chickens from Rev. Joseph Angin - Thunderchild Indian School, Delmas, Sask.

7-9-44

1. This date, while in the Delmas district on other duties, further enquiries were made in this regard. Father Angin was again interviewed and he stated that the two pigs that he had believed were stolen have now returned and he is of the opinion now that they never had been stolen but had merely broken out of the pen and strayed away for a few days. Father Angin further stated that possibly more hens had been killed by dogs and coyotes than he had at first considered likely as he has since learned from farmers in the district that during the past summer the coyotes have been very bad and numerous chickens have been lost throughout the district due to this fact and he is therefore of the opinion that none of the chickens he first reported missing were stolen.

2. Farmers in the district interviewed advised that they have lost quite a number of chickens to coyotes during the past summer and are of the opinion that the same probably happened to the chickens which had been reported stolen from the Indian School. As Father Angin now states that the 2 pigs believed to have been stolen have now returned and he is of the opinion that the chickens were killed by coyotes and not stolen, also that no information could be obtained concerning a possible suspect or any information indicating an actual theft, this file is being considered closed at this detachment.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 21st ultimo, No. 116861, referring to the day school at Morley, I beg to say that the matter does not appear to be very clear or satisfactory. As mentioned in a previous letter, it was the distinct understanding between us and the Department that when the new building for a Boarding School was erected, the day schools on the Reserve would be closed, and this unquestionably involved provision in the Boarding School for all the children of school age. There are Reserves, of course, where the day school is the only provision that can be made; but our experience has been that the ordinary day school gives the minimum of results, and where a Boarding School or Institute, is available, the Indians should be encouraged in every way to send their children. I respectfully suggest that the wiser course at Morley would be to enlarge the Boarding school building so as to accommodate those children that now go to the day school. This would be no financial gain to us, but rather the reverse. As it is now, the Morley Boarding school costs the Missionary Society over $2000 a year in addition to the per capita grant received from the Department; but we feel convinced that such an arrangement would be in the interests of the children on the Reserve. I may say, however, that information from Morley seems to show that in spite of all the commendable efforts of the
Agent and the Missionary, the evils resulting from strong drink are increasing among the people to the detriment of their morals, and their social and industrial condition.

All this makes it still more important that the children be withdrawn as far as possible from contaminating surroundings; especially during the formative years of life, and this can be done only through the medium of Boarding schools and Industrial Institutes.

I am, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

Dear Mr Scott:

As my telegram will have advised you, we had a meeting with the Chief and Councillors re the location of a central school in the Hospital building. I inferred from those who spoke that the Indians wanted the present school continued on the north side, and the old school building opened up as a school on the south side; and were opposed to a central school, and further were opposed to this central school being in the Hospital building.

The man who was interpreter was also the most pronounced against the Hospital being used as a school. One of the chiefs was quite willing to fall into any arrangement adopted by the Government.

The sum total of the discussion as reflected by the few who spoke, was in favor of a school on each side in the old school buildings, and further was against a central school; and inferentially their objection to a central school was on account of the Hospital building being used for it.

I spoke very strongly against the use of the old buildings for school purposes, and with a view of getting right down to the essence of their objections, I asked them: "Will you all be willing to send your children to a central school if the Dept. erect a new school building near the Hospital?" And for a moment I thought this would be satisfactory; when all at once the whole crowd arose and protested and admitted that their objection was not against the Hospital building being used as a school because it had been used as a Hospital, but they wanted the old slip-shod "go-as-you-pleases" school as in the old days. However the one outspoken expression by everyone and repeated again and again was that they wanted their children educated.
I would not advise either the continuance of the present school as it is, or the opening of the old school on the south side as I consider it a waste of time and money for the small result attainable; and from the fact that I learned after the meeting was over that there were several men of considerable influence present who did not like to go against the crowd yet who were in favor of a good clean school in the Hospital. And further from the very strong sentiment evinced in favor of education I would recommend that the Dept. close the school on the north side and open the central school in the Hospital building, and I believe the result will justify such action.

Mr. Niddrie in response to a proposal to take the position as teacher in the Hospital school, sent me a communication before the meeting refusing unconditionally to do so, stating that he believed the Indians were opposed to the use of the Hospital as a school, and that they would not attend; and that he did not feel justified in running counter to what he believed to be the wishes of the Indians, and further that he had a letter from the Dept. (which he produced, dated June 26th.) offering him $500. to continue as teacher where he was for the coming year.

He attended the conference and I think was somewhat nonplussed when the Indians made it plain that their opposition was against a central school anywhere and not because it was the Hospital building.

From my knowledge of the influence Niddrie has with the Indians there is no manner of doubt, that if you continue to keep open his present school, you will not get a child from the north side. But if that school is closed and we could get Niddrie to accept the position at the Hospital school, and I am in hopes that under these circumstances he will; then I think it would be a success.

I think his first reason for refusal was your letter of engagement for another year, and he thought he was safe anyway, and secondly his preference for remaining out of the limelight of civilization living as he does now like an Indian in a little hovel beside the school, cooking for himself.
No teacher living as he does can have a proper or elevating influence on the Indians. If he accepted the new position convention would compel him to conform to his surroundings; and there is no one who would insure the success of the new venture as Niddrie would.

If he still refuses and you close the present school I do not despair of its being a success even in other hands, and I would still advise the same course, and some other suitable person employed, possibly a married man whose wife could cook he doing the chores as well. The nurse in either case remaining on for her own special work.

I did not make any mention of collecting the children and driving them to school. As there was no objection raised to the proposition of a central school on account of distance, I thought it best to reserve this to be put in practice later on if it was found essential to secure attendance.

If Niddrie accepts the new position I think he ought to undertake much of the work now done by the Hospital assistant Christianson (and by this means his services dispensed with) such as milking, attending to stable, hens garden etc. As he would have so much spare time outside of school hours and you will have to pay him a good salary anyway, at least $500. and his board, and for this he ought to give his whole time to the service of the department.

Dr. Bryce and Mr. Fleetham are in full accordance with the views I have expressed.

I will be glad to be of any service to you if you care to make use of me in any further negotiations or arrangements.

Yours sincerely

Dear Paget,

Yours of 3rd. instant received. Re Schools - my opinion is to wait and see whether Indians will send their children to the present Day School this fall. I am inclined to think they will nearly all go hunting, taking their families with them; of course they will return at Xmas. The plan I should adopt would be to open the two Day Schools, north and south, or if the Department would prefer it - open the Hospital as an improved School and tell the Indians straight you had provided them with a good school and it is to them to prove whether they are willing to take advantage of it. I believe they would eventually appreciate it. If this is done there must be no mistake about providing a real good teacher (man) with his wife to cook and provide for the children's meals.

Close the Hospital as an Hospital as quickly as possible, for so long as Indians know it is still there for that purpose, no inducement will bring their children to the place. The Doctors' idea - both of them - is to use it partly as a school and partly as an Hospital; this will not do, and as far as consumptives are concerned amongst Indians you cannot keep them even if they are in Hospital away from their people, and as they get plenty of fresh air at home, you cannot do much more for them. My advice is - close the Hospital and let the Nurse and cook go, and when Indians see it is closed for that purpose, I think they will not further object to the school.

Dear Sir:

I have read with much surprise your letter No. 16861 of January 29th. In reference to same request state that to say the least, the position of teacher at this school is a very thankless and uncertain one. I have lived amongst these people for the last 20 years and been actively engaged in the Indian Work for more than 13 years, and spent the best energies both of body and mind without considering either expense or labor. You will see by your letter of November 29th. You will be interested to know how I have been engaged in the Indian Work. I have tried to carry out your wishes, but have been obliged to the extent of my power, but am sorry that sometimes I have met with very little respect, and no sympathy whatever from some of your representatives at Morley, and these are the very ones who are paid by the Government to support and help the teachers to carry out their work. Indeed I have every reason to believe that my efforts have been mis-represented to the Department. I assure you that I feel flattered or encouraged. The Indians sent me three times last winter to come and teach here, and offered by their own efforts to pay me $50
I have been receiving from the Department the position conditions that I intended writing for your position, but before I had time to do so, your agent at Morley sent his former Mr. Grant to turn me off the Reserve. Of course, the Indians here would not have this offer accepted for me. To save any trouble, and because I had no wish to disturb anyone, I agreed to apply to the Indian Commissioner (then at Winnipeg) for the position of teacher under the recommendation of your agent at Morley at a salary of $50 per month.

Ten days after I wrote that my application was accepted, the salary would be paid, and to commence work right away. This I did, but you know how arrangements are made in regard to salaries. I have tried to be faithful in the discharge of my duties, and carry out all your instructions, and am satisfied that the school has made as good progress as any Indian Day School in the West, and the average has been good when the Indians are at home. Keep the Indians on the Reserve, and will guarantee to keep the school full. Furthermore, so long as I am in charge of this school, I will do my best to push the work along by honest persistent effort. I cannot say more. The little 16 x 12 hole I have been living in is not fit for a pig pen—when the wind is high, I cannot keep a lamp burning in the evening—I could build a good class house 18 x 22 rough cast outside and lined inside for $250 which would be a credit.
To the School. We do not want a high building that is an obstruction for we have high winds, and they strike us here with great force.

Now Sir I have Considerable time on my hands outside of School hours, and on Saturdays, and would be glad to do the repairs needed here if you will afford me. Will guarantee the Workmanship and will be in a position to do it cheaper than you could have it done, by hiring a man in a stranger.

Would you allow us when the Repairs are done to bring the new desks from the Orphanage School road. They are laying idle there, and ours are used up here.

I have Sir the honor to subscribe myself,

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Sir,-

In reply to your letters of December 6th and January 5th., addressed to the Superintendent of Indian Education, I have to inform you that while the Department approves of the procedure outlined, it is questionable whether action should be taken immediately. Undoubtedly foresight would be exercised if the individual parents on the Stony Reserve were to pledge their children for the school before it was erected in order that it might be accurately ascertained what the attendance would be, but at present there is no appropriation for a Boarding School at this point and it does not seem possible to say when funds could be obtained for the purpose. Large demands will be made on the Parliamentary appropriations in order to improve present buildings and to erect new ones. Of course, the work conducted by the Methodist Church would have been considered but at present it would seem premature to ask the Indians to pledge their children for the school unless the erection of a new building on the Reserve within a reasonable time could be promised. It is thought too that the future of the Red Deer Industrial School should be decided before long. It would hardly be possible to consent to erect Boarding Schools on the Northern Reserves, and at the Hobbs and Stony Reserve, and to continue to operate the Red Deer Industrial School.

The day school at Morley has been more or less a failure for many years and I see no prospects of improving methods. The Agent has had instructions from time to time to use his best endeavour to have the Indian parents send their children to school regularly, but of no avail. I would advise that the school be closed and if the plan of establishing an industrial school in the Edmonton district goes through, I would suggest that the Department use compulsion and place these children there. No matter how much Miss Court is liked by the Indian children she will not have sufficient influence to get them to attend school.

Dear Mr. Ferrier -

Referring to official letter of October 23rd, last, and previous correspondence regarding the Morley School, I am convinced that there is no hope of our conducting a successful day school on the reserve at the present time. I think, therefore, that we should withdraw from the work at the end of the present term, and I would ask you to be good enough to advise Miss Court accordingly. MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

In personal communications from the resident missionary on the Morley reserve west of Calgary, information has been brought to my attention concerning the growing desire on the part of the band to have school facilities provided. During the last 12 years 80 young people have grown up on the Morley reserve, only 40 miles from Calgary, without any education whatever. I understand the Indians waited on the agent to ask for a school and Mr. Yeomans promised to refer the matter to Ottawa. I am of the opinion that a residential school is what is needed at this point.

17th Sept. 1909

Sir,

Referring to your letter of

I have enclosed herewith enclosed letter from Mr. Matson Teacher of the Morley Day School respecting a dwelling house which is certainly needed at once provided the Department have considered it advisable to carry on this school.

The place Mr. Matson has been living in since taking charge of the school is a little 10x12 attached to the school and as he states is not fit for a human being to live in.

If as I have already mentioned the Department have decided to keep this school open then I would suggest a building 18x24 or 18x30 one and a half story high with two rooms downstairs and two rooms upstairs with a lean to about 12x18 for kitchen the whole building to be of logs on a stone foundation, lathed and rough cast outside, and lath and plastered inside.

The Secretary

Inside, the cost of which roughly estimated to be about five hundred dollars $500.

The School House I have already estimated for stone foundations, general repairs and painting about $150.

I also estimated for a small house for Teacher $250 but on consideration the larger one would be better, as it would then be available for the accommodation of boys who might wish to stay here and again.

The School is now closed.

Indians are going away for their fall hunt, and Mr. Macdonald could if you feel disposed and have funds available put up the buildings this fall so it is quite possible there will not be many pupils if any until the New Year.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant in which you inform me that it is now decided to continue the day school on the Stony Reserve where it is now in operation. In my opinion the decision was a very prudent one for the present school apparently is located near to where the greatest number of children of this reserve are.

When I recently inspected this school and building I concluded that it was about the best location on the reserve for a day school and that the building could be made to meet the requirements for a number of years with the expenditure of about $150.00. As the location is so near to Easkaw it occurred to me that the best and most lasting material to plaster the exterior wall would be cement. If properly applied it should make an everlasting job.

A log walled building such as the one proposed by Mr. Agent Fleeton will no doubt meet the requirements. A good collar I think should be provided for under the lean-to kitchen. If the smoke pipe from the range is 3" there could be a connecting 4" pipe leading to it from the collar and in that manner draw off the odors which may arise from any vegetables stored therein. It may be well too at the outset to carry the lean-to the full length of the building - 24'. The extra room will doubtless be required and the extra expense will not be great.

Yours obediently,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned from the Province of Alberta, where I have been for nearly three weeks. I visited the Blood, Peigan, Sarcee, Blackfoot, Hobema and Edmonton Agencies, and eight Indian Boarding Schools.

SARCEE AGENCY.

I visited the Sarcee Reserve and am glad to let you know that the hospital-school here is doing excellent work. You would not know it was the same children that we had in this Institution three years ago. There is a complete change. The building is well kept and there is an efficient staff.

Matters on the Reserve are in good shape. I would, however, like to see another fifty head of breeding cows at this Agency. We have pasture and it seems to me we should be raising the cattle.

The system of managing this Reserve is entirely different to what it was before Dr. Murray took it over. It is now carried on in a business way; it never was before.

(Sgd.) W. M. Graham.

Sir:

I have the honor to report on the Sarcee School, which I inspected just before the Christmas Holidays, but did not wish to report on until I got through inspecting the Agency, which inspection I have just completed.

At the time of my inspection there were 26 children registered, and I found that for the fall term, up to the time of my visit, the average attendance was a little over 24.

I found the children looking real well. They were well dressed and looking healthy, and I must say that I was very well impressed with the classroom work, where I spent all afternoon.

You will recall that this school was diverted last summer from a boarding school to a day school. The classroom that was previously used was at the end of the main building, and as it took a great deal of fuel to heat this room the classroom was moved into one of the main dormitories. Additional windows were placed in this room, and blackboards etc., and the teacher advised me that this was very satisfactory. Everything in the classroom was fixed up to the teachers satisfaction.

No difficulty has been experienced in getting the children to come to school regularly, and some of the older ones come on horse-back, others are driven to school and called for by their parents, and where the Indians live together in groups they do this turn about. One wagon brings the children from each group of houses.

A real good mid-day meal is furnished to the children attending, and since January 1st., which will be continued during the winter, before the children go home they are given a lunch, so I would say that they are being looked after pretty well.
As the classroom work is being inspected by the Provincial Inspector of Schools I shall not enlarge on that.

Mr. Gibbon's work has been very satisfactory, and he has been getting good results, as will be shown by the fact that last year three girls wrote on their Entrance and all passed.

One of the girls has since been married, but the other two are still attending school.

Yours obedient servant,

M. Christianson

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the school and hospital on the Sarcee Reserve. As this is not a boarding school there is very little for me to report:

The building that is used as a school and hospital is, as you know, an old and dilapidated one, but it has been kept in a fair state of repair. Mr. Varcoe, who has been doing the carpenter work on the reserve for the last two years has done a great deal of work for us around the school, without any cost to the Department. In such weather as he has been unable to work outside on the reserve he has spent his time in repairing our buildings and I must say the school building looks better than it has for years: Doors and windows have been fitted and walls fixed, floors repaired, &c.

There are 25 children on the register with an average attendance of from 19 to 24.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The children all looked well and come to school regularly. They receive a good midday meal and a lunch before they leave for home at 4.00 o'clock. I have had complaints from the Indians about turning the institution into a day school, but during my inspection there this was not brought up, and the change seems to be working out satisfactorily.

The Reverend Mr. Gibney, teacher, according to the Provincial School Inspector's report, is evidently carrying on very well. Mrs. Gibney gives the girls instructions every week in sewing, embroidery, &c.

As you are aware, cows, chickens, &c., are kept at the school and therefore we have an abundance of milk, eggs, garden truck, &c.

The staff at the school and hospital consists of Miss Henderson as nurse and general worker, and Mrs. Smith as cook and general utility woman. Both these women have been with the Department for a number of years and their work is very satisfactory. I regretted to note that Miss Henderson is in very poor health and has more or less had a breakdown, and is, I would say, in no shape to carry on there. I advised her to apply for some sick leave and I could arrange to place Miss Coleman in charge while she is away, but I doubt if Miss Henderson will take advantage of this as she is under the impression that she cannot afford to go away. These
two women have a great deal or work to do in keeping the building clean, supplying the mid-day meal and lunch for the children. Besides, there are five children kept at the school all the time as they live too far away to come as day pupils. There are always some patients in the hospital and the odd confinement case, so they are certainly kept very busy.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Dear Sir,

The Department has received your letter 408-11A of March 10th, being a report of your inspection of the institution at the Sasee Reserve. Miss Henderson has been a very useful and faithful employee, and the Department regrets that she is not in good health. You are well advised to urge her to take sick leave, and I hope she will be able to do so.

You are aware, of course, that the cost of maintaining this institution has greatly decreased, and the Department's impression, founded on statements from yourself and Doctor Murray, is that its efficiency has not been affected. It is the only place of exactly this kind maintained in the service, and it is possible that it may be a pattern for other places.

All pupils attending this school are from the Sarcee Reserve. Some of these live four and five miles from the school, and either have to be driven, drive themselves, or ride horse-back to school. Inclement weather -- more so in Winter -- lowers the attendance.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Ottawa.
I am attaching hereto a list of names of all children on this reserve at time of my visit. This was prepared, at my request, by Dr. Murray, the Agent.

The teacher, Mr. F.M.R. Gibney, holds a first Class Irish, and second-class Province of Manitoba certificate. He has been teaching at this school since 1930. He is, I think, a capable teacher, has a kind manner in dealing with the children, and the pupils appear to respond to his commands, and answer his questions fairly freely.

The punctuality at this school is not the best: Some children are late in the mornings, and will miss school for any trivial reason. A number of the parents are too easy-going in this respect, and where the child rules the home, it is difficult to compel regular attendance. I believe Mr. Gibney could do more to impress upon the parents the importance of their children attending school. Dr. Murray, the Agent, is very strong on regular attendance: I have heard him lecture parents when we found a child at home without reason, and in some cases the child left for school there and then.

I was not favourably impressed with the condition of the classroom generally on either of my visits: It was not tidy; I doubt if the floor had been swept recently; there were books here and there on unoccupied desks and elsewhere. His own (the teacher's) desk was loaded, pell-mell, with this and that. When I asked him for his quarterly returns and old registers, he did not know where to find them. The whole place was dusty; decorations on the walls needed to be straightened. I
I drew this to Mr. Gibney's attention before leaving, and saw that he felt embarrassed, and said he would attend to same at once.

Classes are held in the hospital building (formerly a residential school) in one of the dormitories on the second floor. Entrance to this classroom is from an inside door at the head of the staircase. This room is long and narrow -- 36' x 16' -- with 14-foot ceiling. The length of the room runs North and South, and there are three fair-sized windows at each end. The South end has also an outside door leading to a closed-in verandah, the upper two-thirds of which is glassed in (sun-room). The lighting is not the best -- I would call it "cross-light." Artificial light (electric) is used on dull days.

The pupils' seats -- 30 in number -- four rows deep, are arranged to face the East wall and blackboards. The west wall, behind the pupils, is a blind one, with a door leading to the staircase and entrance. The teacher's desk faces that of the pupils. However, owing to the length -- probably I should say width -- of the seating arrangements (36 feet) it is difficult for the teacher to supervise (watch) the pupils who occupy the end seats. This is no doubt one of the reasons why Mr. J.A. Macgregor, Provincial School Inspector, reported that the discipline in this school came under the column "low" in his report dated November 7th, 1940. I agree with him that the room is not suitable for the purpose.
We have here a school house with a classroom proper. This is a good, substantial building, located a few feet from the hospital building, and connected thereto by the basement. It is not being used. The reason, I am told, is that having no heating system (furnace) of its own, heat was provided from the hospital steam-heating plant, the operating of which is quite costly (expensive) when having to supply heat to the separate school house, which has four outside walls.

This separate school house has a basement, with concrete walls and floor, and a full-length brick chimney from the basement. If a proper sized -- fairly large -- hot air furnace were installed, I believe this building could be made very comfortable, provided both outside doors are kept properly closed. The teacher, who should be given full charge and responsibility for the heating -- lighting fires and controlling them -- would see that these doors were kept closed.

If it is decided to again make use of this classroom, the interior will have to be redecorated. Provision will also have to be made for outside toilets. At the present time the facilities (water works) which adjoin the classroom (old dormitory) in the hospital building, are being used.

Your obedient servant,

Alberta Inspectorate.
December 11, 1944.

Dr. T. F. Murray, Indian Agent
Sarcee Reserve, Calgary.

Dear Sir:

I am sorry that in the pressure of much going and coming I have omitted to advise you of the arrangements made with Miss Winnifred Tims to carry on the teaching at your day school during the illness of Rev. L. F. Rowe. When we were told that Mr. Rowe was in hospital, it was also suggested that he was worrying a good deal about the children and was most anxious that school should be carried on until the Christmas holidays. We immediately telegraphed Miss Tims, who had kindly assisted us in the interval which occurred before Mr. Rowe arrived. We felt that she knew the school intimately and could carry on for a week or two more readily than a complete stranger. We did not think at the moment that it was necessary to advise the Department as we regarded Mr. Rowe as on sick leave and Miss Tims merely going as a substitute.

In the matter of remuneration, we hope that Mr. Rowe will continue to receive his cheque from the Department, and we—and our Commission will be responsible for paying Miss Tims for the time she is able to render this assistance.

Trusting that this will be satisfactory and regretting the delay in advising you,

Yours sincerely,

HAA/IMA Secretary.
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. of Mines and Resources
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention: Mr. R.A. Hoey.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Sarcee Day School.

I beg to refer to my conversation at the time of my recent visit to Ottawa, and now beg to enclose copy of my letter to the Indian agent, Dr. Murray. I may explain that Mr. Rowe has had a serious attack of pneumonia, and is still confined to the hospital in Calgary. He is a most conscientious man, and we believe it would hasten his progress if his mind could be relieved in regard to the continuance of the school. Miss Tims is able to use her own car and go out to the school daily, as she has to look after her aged parents. She taught in the old residential school and is well known to the Indians and her services are always appreciated.

I gather that a new nurse has been appointed to the hospital and that the building is likely to be put to fuller use for medical purposes as a result. I trust that consideration may be given at the right moment to our suggestion that the day school should be established at a more central point on the reserve, so that it may secure a larger attendance of pupils than appears to have been possible up to date.

Thanking you, and with kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood

Secretary.
Ottawa, December 18, 1944.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, regarding the Saree Indian Day School.

For your information I may say that Inspector Schmidt wrote us on November 14, advising us of Mr. Rowe's illness and recommending the employment of Miss Tims as substitute teacher. We approved this arrangement in a letter dated November 20 and consequently, as far as we know, the school is operating.

At the present time we are developing a plan for post-war reconstruction of buildings required in connection with Indian work throughout Canada. It is our intention to include in this list the necessity for a new school at a more central point on the Saree Reserve.

Yours sincerely,

Acting Director.

Rev. H. A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary,
Indian & Native Residential School Commission, M.M.C.C.,
36-45 The Bible House,
164 Alexander Avenue East,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dec. 18/44
Ottawa, January 26, 1945.

Dr. Thos. P. Murray, Indian Agent, Calgary, Alberta

I desire to refer to your letter of November 18, 1944, addressed to Inspector Schmidt, which he forwarded to this office, regarding the illness of the Reverend L. F. Rowe, teacher at the Sarcee Indian Day School. We subsequently received a medical certificate to the effect that Mr. Rowe would be absent from December 5 to December 15. We have not yet been advised if Mr. Rowe returned to duty and, if so, on what date.

It is our usual custom to allow one month's leave of absence with pay in the case of serious illness of a teacher. The period covered by your medical certificate would be slightly more than this, but we sent Mr. Rowe his cheque for December. We are withholding the January payment until we have definite information from you.

In the event that Mr. Rowe has returned to duty, you should let me know the exact length of time during which Miss Tims taught the school, in order that we may pay her.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Sarcee Agency, Calgary.
January 30th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

With reference your letter No. 120-1-1 of the 26th inst., regarding Reverend L.F. Rowe, teacher of the Sarcee Indian Day School. I beg to state that he is still unable to resume his teaching duties. Miss W.A. Tims has been teaching our school from November 14th to the present date, inclusive and has been paid by the Anglican Missionary Society of Winnipeg up to January 15th. Reverend L.F. Rowe advises me that he may resume his teaching duties within the next week.

[Signature]
H. T. Murray
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 3, 1945.

Ex'D.

Representative of the Treasury.

Re: Sarcee Indian Day School, No. 701.

The January salary for the teacher of this school was held until we had made some inquiries. It is now in order to release this cheque and forward same to the teacher.

The February cheque should not be sent until you hear further from this Branch.

For Deputy Minister.
Sarcee Day School,
Sarcee Reserve,
P.O. Box 129,
Calgary.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Training and Welfare,
Indian Affairs Branch of
Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Early in the New Year when the School Returns were sent to the Agent here we also sent a very much needed Requisition for supplies needed during current term.

So far nothing has arrived and I am at considerable expense personally buying supplies we are short of.

Would you kindly look into this matter and find out if the Requisition has arrived at the Department and if so why no action has been taken.

I realize we should only make the Requisition once yearly in May. However I came here to Sarcee and only time teaches one how much to order. Last year I ordered sufficient for each Pupil to have about three writing books, while I find they can use up six. Other things on the Requisition are in accord with the requirements made by the Alberta School Inspector, to bring our standard up to the Provincial System.

Thanking you in anticipation of some action,

Yours faithfully,

Leonard H. Rowe
(Rw.) Teacher

Dear Sir:-

May I again trouble you in regard to the salary of Rev. L.F. Rowe about which you wrote to us last on May 10th. We had thought that this matter was completely settled at that time but have recently discovered that one monthly cheque does not appear to have been received. We took the matter up with the Comptroller of the Treasury and have a reply dated September 25th admitting that no salary was paid for the month of February 1945 and claiming that this was not issued by reason of request from the Department.

Our records are clear that we are still short of one payment of $113.42 and I shall be grateful if you will verify this and instruct the Treasury to make the payment. You will recall that Mr. Rowe suffered a serious illness and was unable to conduct the school from November 6th 1944 until March 1st 1945. However, after the lapse of one week our Commission secured the services of Miss W. Tims and the school was efficiently maintained until Mr. Rowe was well again. As he was incurring very heavy hospital expenses it was our thought that he required his complete income throughout the period and there was no suggestion on our part that he should turn over the grant from the Department to his substitute. Miss Tims was paid directly by the Commission so that Mr. Rowe might be free from anxiety during his serious illness. It would appear, therefore, that at the present moment the Commission is short by the amount mentioned above.

Commending this matter to your kind attention, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Further to my conversation with you in November I now beg to advise that we have completed arrangements to change the status of the Rev. L.F. Rowe who has hitherto acted as teacher and missionary on the above Reserve. Mr. Rowe will now act in a missionary capacity both among the Indians and in two adjoining white congregations. It is proposed that a Day School teacher shall be appointed and I now beg to recommend to you Miss Winifred Tims of Calgary. You will doubtless recall that Miss Tims taught this school when her father was in charge of the mission and she has assisted us on several occasions when there has been need. She has the reputation of being an excellent teacher and her heart is in the work among the Sarcees. I feel sure that this change will be for the benefit of the pupils and we have encouraged to learn that already this year the level of attendance has been very much higher, probably by reason of family allowances being paid.

We are fixing up a small church building to serve as a teacherage and if this appointment is confirmed by the Indian Affairs Branch Miss Tims will take up residence and commence her duties from the beginning of 1946. Mr. Rowe has advised us that there is something seriously wrong with the heating plant in the school building and I am writing to Mr. Phelan to urge that something should be done to correct this before a new teacher takes over the work. Dear Sir:

As I have recently returned from a visit to several of our schools I think it well to give you a few notes of what I found.

In Calgary I had the pleasure of conference with Acting Inspector Goodman. I had previously met him at Gleichen and am very happy about his appointment. He appeared to co-operate splendidly with Principal House and I believe their united efforts were largely responsible for the successful work done on that reserve.

The Sarcee Day School: There is a very unsatisfactory situation on this reserve and I trust that before long it may be remedied. I understand that the Medical Services are considering some change in regard to the former Residential School which has for some years been used for hospital purposes. Apparently it has been of very little value and has not justified the expenses of maintenance. For some time it has scarcely been used for hospital purposes and has largely been empty and idle. On the other hand, the Day School has taken a new lease of life under the capable and experienced leadership of Miss Winnifred Tims. Her heart is completely in her work and her long knowledge of these Indians and her undoubted skill as a teacher makes her a very valuable worker. I found her full of enthusiasm and very happy about the teacherage which our Commission has provided by making use of the former Parish Hall. She is, however, somewhat discouraged at the poor quarters provided for the school and the many difficulties under which it is carried on. Apparently the school has been sacrificed at almost every point to the hospital. The classroom cannot be made comfortable in cold weather and is really too cramped now that 30 children are on the roll. There are no playroom facilities except in the dusty furnace room underneath. The children are given very little playground as ashes from the hospital are freely dumped in the level space that should be used for the purpose. There are difficulties about stabling and pasturing the horses which bring many of the children to the school and almost at every point it would appear that the school has little privilege while the large building stands empty.

May I urge that consideration be given to closing down the hospital completely and using a greater part of the building to
provide an improved day school. The present classroom could then be used for manual training purposes and better accommodation for teaching be provided in the large building. The children already have their mid-day meal in the dining room and on this basis they could have adequate playrooms. It might be necessary to have the services of a caretaker and cook and possibly a married couple might be secured at small cost for this purpose. This would compare with the cost of four workers which has been met during past years for very little purpose. This suggestion may have points of difficulty that are not present to my mind but I urge it when the disposition of the building is being considered. Any impartial person would agree at once that the interests of the children are now being made secondary to the maintenance of a large building that is practically empty.

St. Paul's, Cardston: I spent several days in this splendid school and feel that it is worthy example of what a residential school should be. I attended the meeting of the Woman's Auxiliary in one of the homes and it was a revelation to hear this group of women conducting their business in excellent manner. These are the product of the school during the years and their present standards are most satisfying.

The chief difficulties our Principal has experienced lately concern the failure of many children to return after the summer vacation and also the vexed matter of whether or not they should be allowed to go home at other times. Apparently many of the absentees were eventually recovered but our Principal still feels that not enough pressure is placed on the parents to compel the attendance of their children. After the return of the children to their homes at such times as Christmas and Easter had been established, as is apparently the custom in a number of schools in southern Alberta, the Agent took a strong line in refusing to allow this. The parents were much concerned and have been inclined to turn their indignation against the Principal so that the school has been losing some of the good-will it has enjoyed. There are various angles to this question that I may be able to discuss with you shortly but it is my feeling that we shall have to concede the point to the parents although it often increases the work of our staff.

St. Cyprian's, Brocket: I was well satisfied with the excellent work being done by our new Principal, Rev. E.S.W. Cole. He and his wife are experienced in Indian work and were throwing themselves into their duties with great enthusiasm. It is encouraging to note that there is an increased population on this reserve and the prospects are that the school will be full to its capacity in the Fall. I took up with Agent McMillan the question of moving our Church Mission House from the village to the school site and he has doubtless referred this matter to you before this. Instead of building a new residence, as requisitioned by the previous Principal, it seemed a good plan to have this building moved to the school and established in a permanent way. It can serve at present for a Farm Instructor or other worker and may later be used by the Principal if the larger number of children expected makes it advisable to use his present quarters in the school.
Old Sun School, Gleichen: I did not visit this school as I was there last February but Principal House decided to take a short holiday and accompany me to the Pacific Coast. His school gives us less trouble than any and we are well satisfied with what is being done there.

St. Michael's, Alert Bay: Mr. House and I visited this school together and it was helpful for him to compare notes with Principal Wickens. We had an excellent display of physical training by the cadets of the school, fully 100 of the older boys and girls giving every creditable display. I have never seen anything better than the marching and general bearing of these children. It is good to know that provision has been made for treating the outer brick work of this building, as the amount of rainfall has made this very necessary. It is much to be desired that the old school building shall be taken down and new classrooms constructed as I believe is planned. As it stands the building is a fire trap and is badly infested with rats.

St. Georges, Lytton: While we have no responsibility for this school Mr. House and I were anxious to see Principal Hives who is rather a lonely man in his present location. By stopping off between trains on the return journey, we spent eight hours at the school. It is truly a very efficient institution and we gained a very favorable impression of the business-like administration of the Principal. The state of the farm was a revelation and made us very envious as we recall the difficult conditions under which most of our school farms are operated. In the evening I had the opportunity of addressing the congregation at the Evening Service in the beautiful stone Church. It was a truly reverent and beautiful service and the singing of the children was delightful. Mr. House and I felt that the spirit of the school was in every way admirable and we were very glad to have had the opportunity of visiting it.

I trust that these notes may have some interest and shall be specially grateful for any action you are able to take to place the Sarcee Day School on a better footing.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Elderwood

Secretary.

Sir,

This will refer to Mr. Gooderham's letter 120-1-1 of August 5, a copy of which I have here.

I concur in all that Mr. Gooderham says about the future of medical and welfare services at the Sarcee Agency, and in particular about the use of the Agency house as a nursing and welfare station. It would seem that this house should provide comfortable quarters for a nurse and for a school-teacher and leave ample space for a few patients, especially maternity cases. The only qualification of Mr. Gooderham's remarks is that I think the downstairs bathroom, which would be used for patients, has no tub, only a toilet and wash basin. A tub could be installed and otherwise I think the building would require no alterations, even if it is not quite what would be built if one were starting from the beginning.

I agree that the old "hospital" and schoolroom are useless, and that a new school should be built. I do not think any provision need be made for resident pupils, but there should be a kitchen where a noon meal could be made. To my mind it would be the better if the kitchen were arranged and equipped to resemble an Indian home kitchen rather than that of an institution. This, I think, should be a part of the school itself.

As for staff, it would seem that one nurse-welfare worker, one teacher and one maid should meet the need. These employees should not be nominated by any church. I see that Mr. Gooderham recommends a 2-room school. Probably he is right, and my comment in this para should read accordingly.

The provision of medical services is bound up with the future of such services at Morley, adequately covered by Mr. Gooderham's letter.

Dear Colonel Neary -

I regret very much that I did not have the chance to talk with you when we were in Ottawa last April. That was entirely because I had a very limited leave from my job. I had intended to be East again this summer but circumstances have ruled that out also.

The matters to which I shall here refer, I have many times discussed with Mr. Gooderham, Inspector of Agencies and with Mr. Hoey. They have also been referred to, in our Brief to the Joint Committee.

We have understood, from what we have been told, that the old building, formerly a residential school and later a most unsatisfactory hospital, at the Sarcee Reserve was to be torn down, the materials salvaged, and a new day school built nearer the center of population on this reserve.

Our Association appreciates the difficulties of the Indian Affairs Branch but we also are here on the spot and appreciate the difficulties these small children have in attending a school which is at least five miles from many of their homes. You must be aware that, under the School Act of this province, children cannot be compelled to attend a school more than three miles by surveyed road from their homes.

Winter in Alberta is a dread prospect. Would you, sir, condemn or encourage your children to ride, drive or walk five miles over a reserve in an Alberta winter to attend school? In addition, they must carry a cold lunch.

That is not conducive to anything except discouragement and is certainly not in accord with any principle of reasonably modern education.

After 27 years of teaching, I feel that I do speak with some knowledge of the child and its problems.

The Sarcees are a fine people and anxious to make up the lost years which maladministration in the past brought to their reserve.
Two weeks ago the Sarcee Band winter and summer schools were opened under the present administration. While the Department of Indian Affairs Board has been unable to provide means by which these schools can be operated, it has been quite possible to keep them in operation. It is now proposed to take advantage of the fact that the schools are now open and have long been closed. As a result of frequent visits to the school by Miss Basile, Roman Catholic missionary at Goodfellow, we believe that all of those who have attended the school will fall for the Catholic faith.

The Department of Pigeon Lake has been unable to offer us everything that we offer our students. We regret that we have given up the opportunity of bringing our students into Boarding School.

We believe that ALL students should be living with their families.

Crescent School wishes success to its students and seniors.

Dear Mr. Laurie:

Colonel Neary:

New Indian Day School at Sarcee:

On this matter I had the advice of the Regional Supervisor, the Superintendent, his assistant (Mr. McLeod) and the Farm instructor. The teacher (Mrs. Watson) was also consulted. Later I attended a meeting of the Chief and Council together with heads of large families and got their reactions to various sites proposed on a map. Afterwards, with Mr. McLeod and the Chief, I explored the ground by "Jeep" - cars are not much use in the reserve and Indian children usually ride horses.

As the patrons of the school are practically unanimous for a "community-centered" school, the site finally chosen and marked with a small pile of stones lies about one hundred yards west of a pump recently installed about a quarter of a mile north of NIGHT village, with MANY HOUSES village to the northwest and STARLIGHT village a little farther to the north. On the Army map of Camp Sarcee this would be map point 044324. This puts the school about three miles northwest of the present school. The trend of settlement and new houses will be to the northwest.

The surrounding land is fairly flat, and slopes gently to the west and south. Water appears to be available, and
electricity is not more than two miles away. Several trails approach the site.

2 SIZE: There are presently forty pupils enrolled. In good weather attendance averaged 29; some children coming over six miles. Four pupils attend a nearer Alberta school.

Based on a study of Family Allowance payments, it is clear that there are now 46 eligible pupils. For the next seven years the figures will be:

50, 51, 51, 56, 57, 62, 58

As the Alberta curriculum puts the emphasis on organization to complete Grade 9, and the Indians wish their children to be given the chance to go further, the resulting combination of numbers of pupils and grades indicates the necessity for a two-room school.

A full basement for various purposes is necessary.

A horse shelter is also a requirement.

Quarters for two teachers should have to be provided.

C.A.J. Clark

Re: Day School Reserve

Attached hereto is the report Mr. Clark has made after his survey. I concur entirely with what he has to say. The location is central, but cannot at the present time be served with any modern facilities. The Indians realize that fact. It is to be noted, however, that the site picked for the school is only a couple of miles from a power line, and that a road can be easily made between the school and the main highway.

The old school is situated at the Agency and should not be used if a new school is erected. Furthermore, it could not be used in conjunction with a new school so it would supply the pupilage in all grades. There is therefore no alternative but to erect a two-room school at the new site, if we are prepared to give the proper educational facilities.

Mrs. Watson, the present teacher, was well recommended. She is doing a splendid job with these Indians and would be prepared to stay as one of the teachers, but states definitely that she may not remain if only a one-room school is erected. She is conscientious, and realizes not only would the work be very heavy, but would not be satisfactory.

I sincerely hope that arrangements can be made to put up a two-room school as the extra cost would not be great. This should be given immediate consideration so that no time will be lost in calling for tenders and starting erection.

It is to be added that Mr. Laurie of the Indian Association is very familiar with the reserve and the school situation. I know he agrees that the proper site has been chosen, and I am sure that he will ask, on behalf of the Indians, for a two-room school.

Mr. Clark and I conferred at some length before we agreed to submit our findings jointly.

Sarcee Indian Day School.

We have had an opportunity of thoroughly studying the report submitted by Major Clark upon the site, size of school, etc., for the Sarcee Indians.

We are quite prepared to accept recommendations made with regard to the site and to erect a school near Point 03324 on the Army Map of Camp Sarcee.

Re: Sarcee Indian School

Your file 120-1-1 (E).

Your letter of the 2nd was brought up for consideration on my return this week from the north. Fortunately, Major Clark arrived in Calgary on the 14th and I was glad to get his report on school sites in various places in the province, and particularly his repercussions at Nordegg, before we discussed the Sarcee situation.

We agreed that the Sarcee Indians should be served by a two-roomed school if they were to be given the proper attention, and now was the time to supply the facilities which would meet requirements possibly for all time. The question arose as to what group or body of Indians could do without a school for the time being, in order to release sufficient funds to build this two-roomed school at Sarcee.

The conclusion was that it must be the Nordegg group, where there will not likely be more than ten pupils for some time. However, we were loath to make any move or suggestion until we discussed it with John Laurie. I therefore called him in to confer with Mr. Clark and myself at this office yesterday.

We agreed that the Sarcee Indians should have a two-roomed school. To release sufficient funds to make up the difference in cost between the one and two-roomed school, it was felt that this can be done without creating a hardship to any other group of Indians, by changing the plan of school structure for the Nordegg Indians. Mr. Clark has had considerable experience in bush life and living and teaching in log schools, and so has Mr. Laurie. In fact, Mr. Laurie at one time lived in the Nordegg country. Both were in total agreement that log buildings for the school and teacherage would be most suitable at Nordegg, and can be erected at very much less cost than the school of your plan. It was further agreed by Mr. Laurie that the Nordegg Indians should not expect a school this year.

Enclosed with this letter is a report from Major Clark with numerous pictures, and a proposed school for the Nordegg Indians. There is nothing more for me to say; his information is most complete and instructive.

I did tell Messrs. Clark and Laurie that I was going to ask for an accountable cheque to cover the costs.
of logs, digging of cellar and drilling of well, all of which should be done this year.

I called Superintendent Pugh in and discussed this with him today, and he agreed that it would be good business to give the Indians work in getting out logs and possibly in digging the cellar, and even in doing some of the concrete work. It is estimated that the cost of getting out 300 logs, 30 to 40 ft. long, would be about $750.00. The drilling of a well, with material and labor, is estimated at $400.00. Excavation and certain concrete work is estimated at $850.00 to $1000.00.

If Mr. Pugh were given an accountable cheque for $2,000.00, we are of the opinion that practically everything that could be done this year towards the erection of a school and teacherage can be carried out in season, and the logs left to dry out for use in 1949. The Indians would earn the major part of this money.

In other words, I am asking that you authorize the erection of a two-roomed school at Sarcee, and give an accountable cheque of $2,000.00 for Nordegg this year. Our building program is going slowly, and it is my conjecture that you can release $2,000.00 and still keep it within your appropriation.

If you concur, please wire as Mr. Pugh is already conferring with builders regarding the erection of the school at Sarcee, and would make arrangements with his Assistant, Mr. Thomas, at Rocky Mountain House to start the Indians to work at Nordegg.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Re: Sarcee Indian Day School

I am in receipt of yours of the 12th, file 1-1-1 X (E). Copies were sent to Superintendent Pugh and Assistant Agent MacLeod, Sarcee.

During the Easter holidays we discussed the possibility of opening the new school at the beginning of the new term. Neither the furnishings for the residence nor the desks had arrived and it was decided that the school must be continued in the old building.

Mrs. Watson appealed to Mr. MacLeod for a second teacher to assist her and stated she was not physically capable of carrying on alone. We did not think we would be justified in inviting Mr. Fresley of Brandon to move now, as there was no accommodation for him and his wife and since there was only two months remaining in the school year.

Fortune, however, was with us I believe when Mr. W. Paul Smith, a young gentleman, whose home is in Calgary, indicated that he might be interested in taking on this work for a couple of months. This was on the 23rd when I wired you.

He interviewed me on the 25th and I was favourably impressed. He is now completing his third year of a four year course in the Faculty of Education, University of Alberta. He has taught three years in rural schools, holds permanent elementary and intermediate school certificates and also a permanent junior certificate for high school. He is single, age 23 and a Protestant, Nazarene denomination.

As he was writing his final examination in Edmonton today and had been offered a school at Lac La Biche, he had to be advised whether or not we wanted his services at Sarcee. We, therefore, went out to the Agency and inspected the present school and the new school. Mrs. Watson welcomed us and it was apparent that she might have a break-down if she did not have some assistance immediately.

I, therefore, suggested that we open a second classroom in the existing school and make temporary arrangements for blackboards and seating capacity. It was also agreed that the school will be carried on here until all equipment for the new school has arrived and is set up in the school. Then it is to be opened with proper ceremony.
April 26th, 1949.

Mr. Smith is prepared to accept the wage of $168.00 per month as quoted in your wire. He will start teaching on the 2nd of May and, on his return from Edmonton this week, will confer with Mrs. Watson as to how they will divide the classes and the work. He is completing an application form and when received at this office, it will be forwarded to you.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Superintendent of Education:

Sarcee (Old School)

With Mr. McLeod I visited this school on June 15.

Although two school divisions are now being conducted only one register is used. It contains forty-two names.

Mrs. Watson handles the first four grades in which there are thirty pupils enrolled. Sixteen were present.

Mr. Smith teaches Grades five and six in which twelve pupils are enrolled. Eight were present. Although the room in which this group works is in the basement, it was well-kept and the children seemed content to be there. Mr. Smith's enthusiasm in the classroom and on the playground is giving these children an impetus.

Mrs. Watson's room, on the contrary, was not at its best. I think she lacks the nervous force to maintain a daily minimum standard over a period of years. There was a suspicion of rationalization in her remark that she felt two years in one place is long enough. It would be well to obtain from her a written statement of her intentions for employment for next year. After June 20th most Alberta teachers are committed to return to their present schools.

Mr. Smith will likely go back to college in the Autumn.

The probability is that the new school will require new teachers.

C.A.F. Clark

Superintendent of Education:

NEW SCHOOL AT SARCEE:

Mr. McLeod took me out to see the new building yesterday.

Some of the furniture has arrived but there is not enough to meet a situation such as might arise if, say, a married couple were living in the upper storey and another teacher wishes to live apart in the "basement suite".

I wish we could avoid engaging married couples that include able-bodied husbands who work only part-time if at all. This reversal of the usual bread-winning tradition cannot be the best sort of example on an Indian reserve.

A second teacher may, of course, find an alternative boarding-house within three miles (with white families) when the projected road is completed.

The contractor has left on the premises a shed (which he wishes to sell or remove) formerly used for the storage of materials. This might be acquired by the Department and adapted for use as a stable for the children's horses so that these poor beasts are not exposed to the elements all day long.

The well-built outdoor toilets are equipped with buckets which will likely become a problem. It is suggested that winter temperatures make pits advisable.

Although the classroom windows face north, the illumination yesterday (a fairly dull, overcast sky) was acceptable. It could be questionable on a dull day in December or January, but Alberta boasts more sunny days than other parts of Canada, and we might have to re-consider the orienting of schools there or extend the eaves in the Manitoba manner to eliminate summer glare.

I am attaching a letter written by Superintendent Pugh in answer to a letter signature of Mr. Phelan, in respect to a voucher in favor of a substitute school teacher at the Sarcee Indian day school.

If I had been asked to find a substitute for Mrs. Watson while she was ill and considered that it was necessary, I would have wired for authority. Mr. Pugh and his assistant did not do so but they did believe that it was necessary to have a substitute and assumed the responsibility of employing Mr. Williams. This young man will, therefore, look to somebody for payment. Should it be Mrs. Watson, Mr. Pugh, Mr. MacLeod or the Department?

It is known that School Boards and Superintendents of schools must at times be prepared to employ substitute teachers and the same condition is bound arise at our day schools. What is the policy when the teacher is ill at an Indian Day School? If it is the policy to employ a substitute teacher when it is necessary, then I believe some consideration should be given to the payment of this voucher.

It is very easy to come to a conclusion that Mr. Williams saw an opportunity to earn some money and that Mr. Smith impressed upon the Assistant Agent, the need of an assistant while Mrs. Watson was ill. However, as Mr. Pugh has stated, we have indicated that this school requires two teachers and we were, therefore, fortunate in having available the services of Mr. Williams. I don't think the Department of Indian Affairs should expect this young man to give his services for nothing, do you? I ask you to please consider this and in any event must ask, what is the policy in regard to the employment of substitute teachers; this must be known for future guidance.

Sarcee Indian School
Officially Opened

First Such Institution in Southern Area
Equipped to Modern Standards; 45 to Attend

The new Sarcee Indian Reserve school which accommodates 45 children from Grades I to VII, was officially opened Tuesday evening by D. S. Harkness, G.M., M.P. for East Calgary.

The new school is the first Indian day school in Southern Alberta equipped to modern standards by the department of Indian affairs. Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Chapa are teachers of the two-room school which has been located so the maximum number of Sarcee children may attend.

G. H. GOODERHAM, Calgary, Alberta superintendent of Indian affairs branch, told 90 Sarcees who attended the opening that 13 day schools, mostly in Northern Alberta, opened Tuesday, and the policy was to establish day schools wherever practical.

Mr. Harkness said he hoped more Indians boys and girls would soon be able to enter high schools and universities and that shortly qualified Indian teachers would be available for the new schools.

He mentioned the work of the joint commission which recommended to the federal government changes in the Indian Act. "However, the government has not seen fit to implement our recommendations yet," he said. "The act was last revised 50 years ago."

JOHN LAURIE, honorary secretary of the Indian Association of Alberta, stressed the need for parents to cooperate with the school. Proper home training of children was essential if the school was to be successful.

Chief David Crowchild announced that two silver medals would be awarded at the end of the school year to the boy and girl who showed the most improvement for school attendance, co-operation with their teachers and parents, character and conduct.

Other speakers were Pat Grasshopper, an elder of the tribe; Robert Warren, head of Southern Alberta's Mrs. E. H. Boalch of the national executive of the Canadian Federation of Home and School Associations.

City Award Won For Third Time

W. Dennis Engels, 366 Centre St., S., has been awarded his third $300 annual Calgary scholarship to the University of Alberta. Aid. Fred Parker, chairman of the civic scholarship committee, announced Tuesday night.

Mr. Engels won the scholarship for his first three years at the university. Two other scholarships have been awarded for the past three years and the city's first scholarship graduate is Patricia Smith, The 4th St., N.E., who graduated in commerce this year. She had won two years in a row.

THE THIRD YEAR scholarship was won this year by Norma Marie Fleddjohn, 1615 Shelbourne St. She also won a scholarship in 1947.

Two second year scholarships, also worth $300 were awarded to Helgi Lavergne Austman, 2018 7th Ave. N.W.; and Penelope Knoll, Chester Rd. 18th Ave. The two second year scholarships were granted to Eric S. Eichmann, 2407 14th St. W. and Mary Isabella Robinson, 3046 3rd St. W.

There were 16 applicants for scholarships this year. The awards and the awards are based on scholastic ability and need, and are paid for by the city of Calgary.

Sarcee Reserve Open School

A reception was held at Sarcee Reserve, Tuesday night, to mark the opening of the two-room school staffed by Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Chabba. It is the first "modern" day school the Indian Affairs branch has erected in southern Alberta.

Speaking of education, Chief David Crowchild described it as "doing one good thing well, and spending spare time wisely." Chief Crowchild acted as chairman.

G. H. Gooderham, regional supervisor of Indian Reserves, presented "official greetings" to the Scarce peoples and said there were 13 day schools opened in the province Tuesday and others would open as soon as teachers were available.

Col. D. S. Harness, M.P. for East Calgary, stressed the need for education among Indian peoples. Robert Warren, High School Inspector for southern Alberta expressed the hope that more Indians would soon be able to enter High schools and colleges.

Other speakers were Mrs. E. H. Boalch, in behalf of the Home and School Associations, of which she is a national chairman; John Laurie, for the Indian Association of Alberta; Pat Grassopper, speaking for the Sarcee behalf of the people of the tribe.

Tea was served by the parents of schoolchildren, convened by Mrs. David Crowchild.

Ottawa, March 13th, 1926.

Sir,

I have your No. 405-11 of the 9th instant, relative to the request of Miss W. Tims, teacher of the Sarcee Indian Day School, to be allowed to teach on public holidays and during Easter week until the end of June, next, such extra time to be credited to her for the month of September.

In reply I beg to say that the Department does not approve of the school being conducted other than the regular teaching days, as it is considered that it would not be fair to the Indian children. In order, however, to facilitate the arrangements which the teacher proposes to make to visit Europe this coming summer, the Department will be prepared to allow her leave of absence with pay until the middle of October, provided arrangements can be made for a substitute teacher to carry on during her absence. The substitute can be paid as an assistant teacher. This arrangement is made in consideration of Miss Tims' faithful service, and is not to form a precedent for any future cases that may arise, as all such will be dealt with on their respective merits. The name, qualifications and experience of the substitute teacher engaged should be forwarded for the information of the Department.

Please inform Miss Tims and the local Indian Agent accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Oct 12th, 1893.

Re School Building
Sarcee Indian Reserve, Alta., W.T."

"Apart from instructions we have surveyed the above building and beg to report as follows:
This building was erected 7 years ago; it is built of logs with shingled roof inside. The internally, the walls & ceiling are lined with beaded tongue & grooved wainscoting.
The building is by no means proof against cold air, the windows frames are poor & out of repair, the chimney & between the logs is defective in many places & the logs themselves are full of snake, also the roof is not tight at the wall plates, consequently it is not surprising that the building prove to be very cold in winter. The bottom logs & cells are more or less rotten & decayed. The building is quite unsuitable for school purposes, being very low & having an 45 sq ft to each child's cubic capacity for only eight persons. This includes the small recess at end. The floor space of school room at 10 sq ft to each, would accommodate 32 persons, but the width of the building being only 16' 0", this could not be readily or conveniently done. 16' 0" is altogether too narrow for a school room & the capacity of the room..."
The school-room is rather dark; the windows which are two in number, and consist of panes each of 10 x 12" glass; they are on one side of the room. The tops of their sills are only 15" above the floor, and consequently much useful light is lost, being obstructed by desks &c. We are given to understand that it is proposed with a view of enlarging this school-room, to build a log building similar in all respects to the building in question & adding it on to the same; this will prove to be a very costly & difficult undertaking; the country being very hilly.

On the other hand should the said building be pulled down instead, with a view of utilizing the old materials, we would point out that in stripping off the "wainscoting" on walls & ceiling, the tongues & grooves would be more or less split off and destroyed, thereby destroying the usefulness of same in a great measure. Whichever of these plans is adopted it will prove more costly and less satisfactory than making use of new materials for a new addition or enlargement; but whatever is done the roof of the present building should be raised to increased the cubic capacity to something like what it should be. This will also apply to any new addition.

We are of opinion that the most satisfactory plan, and the most economical to adopt, is to erect an entirely new building of lumber & concrete on stout foundations.
Construct same in accordance with the regulations of the department. Such a building to accommodate between 30 & 40 children would cost about $600; and perhaps a little less if part of the work was done by the staff on the Reserve.

Enclosed is a rough sketch plan and section which will give an idea of what the present building is like.

Your obedient servants

(Sgd) Child & Wilson

The building has no ventilation whatever to speak of beyond a hole in the ceiling through which the air escapes into the roof to take its chance of escape through what chinks & cracks it may find.

Dear Sir,

I reply to a letter from the Office of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, addressed to yourself, a copy of which is before me. I beg to remark that my first communication with the Department on the subject of the need of larger accommodation for the children under our care, was through your office on or about the 25th September last. A few days later in a letter dated 2nd October 1893, addressed to the Indian Commissioner direct, I wrote (inter alia) as follows—“In view of a larger number of children, I have made requisition through the Agent for the enlargement of the School building, and have suggested the use of the West Camp School house for the purpose.”

This letter was duly acknowledged on the 6th of the same month, when I was informed that the Agent had been communicated with, and instructed in the matter. In consequence of this last communication, I thought the proper course would be for me to get the best advice on this matter I could, and therefore wrote immediately to Mr. Child & Wilson, of Calgary, who have been architects for most of the buildings on our four Reserves, and knew also the views of the Commissioner on the subject of ventilation, so I asked his advice as to the most economical and satisfactory course to pursue. Their original report dated 12th October 1893, was forwarded to the Department, through
through your office, a copy of which, in case it has been utilized I now enclose. From this report it will be seen that the proposal at first made would not be at all satisfactory.

Both buildings—viz., the one adjacent to the boarding school, and that still at the West Camp, are not large enough for our purposes. They are equal to one another in size and taken together cubi capacity for not more than sixteen children. We have already 25 children (17 boys and 8 girls) in our house, and expect at least 5 more before the end of the present fiscal year. We are willing and indeed anxious to do our utmost to curtail the cost of a new building, and if you are able to help in the way you kindly suggested in October last, I think there can be no doubt that a very suitable frame building can be erected for $600. A further perusal of the Architect's report will, I feel sure, show the wisdom of putting up a new building in the place of the patchwork plan first proposed. A building 20' x 30' ft. and a 16' foot ceiling will give the required accommodation I believe. I shall be happy to furnish full particulars of a suitable structure if requested to do so.

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 9th instant, transmitting memoranda from the Rev. Mr. Stocken relative to the necessity for and cost of an addition to the Boys' Home, and in reply to inform you as follows.

When the Department enters into any educational undertaking on the understanding that it is on a certain scale, it causes it no small amount of embarrassment to have unforeseen and unexpected demands made upon it in connection with the same, and can only meet them by cramping itself in other directions, and endangering other interests.

In the case in point this has been felt so strongly, on account of calls in other directions, that Mr. Stocken has already been told that there seemed no other way out of the difficulty than to keep the number of pupils to within the limit justified by the available accommodation.

In Mr. Stocken's case, however, the Department would stretch a point in a way it would do for a very few, because it has always recognised an endeavour on his part to assist its Agents in carrying out the Department's policy, and a readiness to defend such policy when attacked by people who apparently did

His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan and Calgary,
