Calgary,
N.W.T.
did not themselves understand it, or desired to present it in an improper light to the public.

In recognition, therefore, of such services, the Department has been searching for some means by which to meet Mr. Stocken's desire, and although unable to find funds directly in the school appropriation, the following plan has occurred to it as feasible.

There is a moderate appropriation for hospital building for the benefit of the Blackfoot, and if the old school building which Mr. Stocken considers so insufficient for class room purpose can be made to serve for a hospital for the Reserve, then the sum of $360, which might otherwise be expended in providing such a building, might without impropriety be devoted to providing the new class rooms asked for. This need not interfere with proceeding with the erection of the hospital at the Blackfoot Reserve, if Your Lordship be prepared to proceed with that matter, but it will not be forgotten that the hospital is only authorized on the understanding already reached, that it is to be conducted without any call upon the Department for any further contribution than that for the first cost of building and furnishing.

Dear Sir,

I reply to a letter from the office of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, addressed to yourself, a copy of which is before me. I beg to remark that my first communication with the Department on the subject of the need of larger accommodation for the tuition of the children under our care, was through your office on or about the 25th September last. A few days later in a letter dated 2nd October 1893, addressed to the Indian Commissioner direct, I wrote (inter alia) as follows—“In view of a larger number of children, I have made application through the Agent for the enlargement of the School building, and have suggested the use of the West Camp School house for the purpose.”

This letter was duly acknowledged on the 6th of the same month, where I was informed that the Agent had been communicated with, and instructed in the matter. In consequence of this last communication, I thought the proper course would be for me to get the best advice on the matter I could, and therefore wrote immediately to Mr. Fred Wilson, of Calgary, who have been architect for much of the buildings on our four Reserves, & knew also the views of the Commissioner on the subject of ventilation as I asked his advice as to the most economical and satisfactory course to pursue. His original report dated 12th October 1893, was forwarded to the Department.
through your office, a copy of which, I am sure it has been received by you earlier. From this report it will be seen that the proposal I had first made would not be at all satisfactory.

Both buildings—viz., the one adjacent to the boarding school, and that still at the West Camp—are not large enough for our purposes; they are equal in size and taken together, their capacity for not more than sixteen children. We have already 25 children (17 boys and 8 girls) in our house, and expect at least 5 more before the end of the present fiscal year. We are willing and indeed anxious to do our utmost to curtail the cost of a new building, and if you are able to help in the way you kindly suggested in October last, I think there can be no doubt that a very suitable frame building can be erected for $100. A further perusal of the Architect's report will, I feel sure, show the wisdom of putting up a new building in the place of the patched-up old building proposed. A building 20 ft. x 30 ft. and a 16 foot ceiling will give the required accommodation I believe. I shall be happy to furnish full particulars of a suitable structure if requested to do so.

I am dear Sir,

Yours faithfully,

Oct 12th 1893

School Building
Sarcee Indian Reserve, Alta N.W.T."

According to instructions we have surveyed the above building and beg to report as follows:

This building was erected 7 years ago; it is built of logs with shingled roof inside. The internally, the walls & ceiling are lined with beaded tongues & grooved wainscoting.

The building is by no means proof against cold air, the window frames are poor & out of repair, the chimney & between the logs is defective in many places & the logs themselves are full of snake, also the roof is not tight at the wall plates, consequently it is not surprising that the building proves to be very cold in winter. The bottom logs & cells are more or less rotten & decayed.

The building is quite unsuitable for school purposes, being very low & having an 45 sq ft each [child] cubic capacity for only eight persons. This includes the small recess at end. The floor space of school room at 100 sq ft to each would accommodate 32 persons, but the width of the building being only 16' 0", this could not be readily or conveniently done. 16' 0" is altogether too narrow for a school room & the capacity of the room is...
decreased by book-closet, store &c.

The school-room is rather dark; the windows which are two in number, and consist of panes each of 10 x 12" glass; they are on one side of the room. The tops of their sills are only 15" above the floor, and consequently much useful light is lost, being obstructed by desks &c. We are glad to understand that it is proposed with a view of enlarging this school-room, to build boldly from a distance of 5 miles a log building similar in all respects to the building in question & adding it on to the same. This will prove to be a very costly & difficult undertaking; the country being very stiff. On the other hand should the said building be pulled down instead, with a view of utilizing the old materials, we would point out that in stripping off the wainscoting on walls & ceiling, the tongues &c. of same would be more or less split off and destroyed, thereby destroying the usefulness of same in a great measure. Whichever of these plans is adopted it will prove more costly and less satisfactory than making use of new materials for a new addition or enlargement; but whatever is done the roof of the present building should be raised to increased the cubic capacity to something like what it should be. This will also apply to any new addition.

We are of opinion that the most satisfactory plan, and the most economical to adopt, is to erect an entirely new building of lumber with concrete or stone foundation.
Construct same in accordance with the regulations of the department. Such a building to accommodate between 30 & 40 children would cost about $600; and perhaps a little less if part of the work was done by the staff on the Reserve.

Enclosed is a rough sketch plan and section which will give an idea of what the present building is like.

Your obedient servants
